title: Trump and the EU Dodge a Trade War
content: The U.S. President gets his beloved 15% tariff but little else from Europe.

title: For Trump, E.U. Trade Deal was Badly Needed
content: After a lot of big talk on trade, the Trump administration needed a big win. It appears to have just gotten one.
resumen: President Trump announced a trade agreement with the European Union on Sunday. The deal is his biggest trade deal to date. After going months without securing deals, Mr. Trump is now coming off his most productive stretch of trade negotiations, landing agreements in recent days with the Philippines, Japan and Indonesia as well as the European Union, which represents 27 countries. The European Union and the United States agreed on Sunday to a broad-brush trade deal that sets a 15 percent tariff on most E.U. goods. The European Union also agreed to purchase $750 billion of American energy, which Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the E.U.‚Äôs executive branch, said would be spread out over three years. The bloc also agreed to increase its investment in the United States by more than $600 billion. The two sides agreed to drop tariffs to zero on a range of goods including aircraft, plane parts, certain chemicals, certain generic drugs, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products, Ms. von der Leyen said.

Altos negociadores estadounidenses y chinos se re√∫nen el lunes en Estocolmo para abordar las disputas econ√≥micas en el centro de la guerra comercial entre ambos pa√≠ses, con el objetivo de extender una tregua que mantenga a raya unos aranceles m√°s altos.

Las conversaciones en Estocolmo, lideradas por el secretario del Tesoro estadounidense, Scott Bessent, y el viceprimer ministro chino, He Lifeng, tienen lugar un d√≠a despu√©s de que la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, se re√∫na con Trump en su campo de golf de Escocia para tratar de cerrar un acuerdo que probablemente supondr√≠a un arancel de base del 15% para la mayor√≠a de los productos de la UE.

Dos de los principales funcionarios comerciales de Trump, el secretario de Comercio, Howard Lutnick, y el representante comercial de Estados Unidos, Jamieson Greer, asistir√°n a las conversaciones de Escocia y luego viajar√°n a Estocolmo.

Se est√°n planteando centros de producci√≥n integral de carne.

resumen: La presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, y el presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, han alcanzado un acuerdo para resolver su disputa comercial sobre el aumento de aranceles, con el establecimiento de grav√°menes del 15 por ciento para productos europeos y compromete al bloque europeo a inversiones adicionales as√≠ como adquisiciones de energ√≠a y armamento. La industria mexicana busca nuevos caminos para responder al vendaval arancelario de Trump. M√©xico apuesta por incrementar su mercado interno y trata de diversificar sus exportaciones ante la volatilidad de su principal socio comercial.

Para este sector, un aumento arancelario, como el prometido por la Administraci√≥n de Donald Trump, representar√≠a un aumento de precios imponderable. Tambi√©n para buscar nuevos mercados de exportaci√≥n, un proyecto que tanto el Gobierno de Claudia Sheinbaum como el sector privado reconocen como ambicioso. Vidal Llerenas Morales, subsecretario de Industria y Comercio, se√±ala que, para el gobierno, lleg√≥ la hora de hacer ‚Äúpol√≠tica industrial‚Äù, invocando un concepto relacionado al programa de reconstrucci√≥n posguerra conocido como el Plan Marshall. M√©xico va a seguir exportando a Estados Unidos, pero tambi√©n se tendr√≠a que abrir a otros sectores, como producir m√°s autos para el mercado nacional y para otros que no consumen lo que ahora producen, que b√°sicamente son autos de alta gama con motor de combusti√≥n para Estados Unidos, agregando potencialidades para aumentar la producci√≥n local de f√°rmacos, ropa, calzado o equipos m√©dicos. La electromovilidad es una oportunidad mirando a Europa y Am√©rica Latina.

Para lograr un proyecto de esta magnitud se requerir√° m√°s que un sexenio. Desde la Secretar√≠a de Econom√≠a, comandada por Marcelo Ebrard, sostienen que la atracci√≥n de capital extranjero est√° en marcha, aunque sin revelar nuevas inyecciones para la segunda mitad del a√±o. El Plan M√©xico, la hoja de ruta de la presidenta, incluye un portafolio de inversiones, nacionales y extranjeras, de 277.000 millones de d√≥lares y la atracci√≥n de unas 2.000 empresas que se quieren radicar en el pa√≠s, particularmente en zonas bautizadas como Polos de Desarrollo Econ√≥mico para el Bienestar. Llerenas agrega que hay dos tipos de polos de desarrollo que se est√°n planteando: en lugares m√°s aislados y m√°s al sur del pa√≠s, con mayores incentivos fiscales y donde hay mayores niveles de pobreza, y tambi√©n los polos de desarrollo donde se pueda hacer offshore. Isaac Cruz, analista del Instituto Mexicano para la Competitividad (IMCO), dice que la estrategia est√° enviando se√±ales ‚Äúalentadoras‚Äù al mercado. M√©xico no tiene el entorno resuelto en √°reas medulares como generaci√≥n de agua y energ√≠a, incubaci√≥n de talento o seguridad jur√≠dica y ciudadana.

El gobierno ha relanzado su marca Hecho en M√©xico, un programa que incluye capacitaci√≥n y financiamiento con fondos p√∫blicos para incentivar la producci√≥n local. B√°rbara Botello, encargada del programa, dice que M√©xico es un M√©xico moderno que est√° haciendo aviones, dispositivos electr√≥nicos, semiconductores y que puede producir lo que consume y no tiene por qu√© estar importando tantas cosas.

El T-MEC estar√° vigente hasta el 2036, y si en la revisi√≥n no se llegara a un acuerdo, la ruta es mantenerlo tal y como est√° redactado. Barbuza, el representante gremial de la industria mexicana del cuidado personal, dice que se est√°n preparando para tener una agenda propositiva y no jugar a la defensiva, porque el juego de poner barreras es perder-perder.

title: China comunista pierde terreno en telecomunicaciones, litio y transporte en Am√©rica Latina
content: Lea aqu√≠ la columna de opini√≥n de Arturo McFields, exembajador de Nicaragua ante la OEA y miembro del Cuerpo de Paz de Noruega. | Arturo McFields ...
resumen:
China comunista ha venido creciendo a paso acelerado en Am√©rica Latina en las dos √∫ltimas d√©cadas, sin embargo, en los √∫ltimos meses las cosas han comenzado a cambiar. La llegada del presidente Trump ha golpeado los negocios de china en sectores como litio, transporte y telecomunicaciones.

China est√° perdiendo terreno en M√©xico. BYD, la mayor empresa de coches el√©ctricos del mundo y principal competidor de Tesla, de Elon Musk, anunci√≥ la cancelaci√≥n de la construcci√≥n de una planta multimillonaria de veh√≠culos el√©ctricos en M√©xico. El proyecto de BYD tendr√≠a capacidad para producir hasta 150.000 coches al a√±o.

En el sector minero de Ecuador, China tambi√©n sufri√≥ un duro rev√©s. La empresa Terraearth Resources cancel√≥ cuatro proyectos despu√©s de que el gobierno ecuatoriano decidiera suspender las actividades de exploraci√≥n y explotaci√≥n debido al incumplimiento de las regulaciones ambientales.

La estrategia comunista para el control total del litio tambi√©n est√° fracasando y generando grandes p√©rdidas. BYD y Tsingshan, dos importantes empresas chinas, frustraron sus planes de construir plantas de procesamiento de litio en Chile valoradas en 500 millones de d√≥lares. Chile posee una de las mayores reservas de litio del mundo.

Los fracasos y retrasos de los proyectos de empresas chinas en Latinoam√©rica no son casuales, sino consecuenciales; son resultado de la nueva pol√≠tica exterior de Estados Unidos. El primer viaje internacional del Secretario de Estado, Marco Rubio, no fue a Europa ni Asia, sino a Centroam√©rica. Esta visita supuso el fin de la Iniciativa de la Franja y la Ruta (BRI) firmada entre Panam√° y China.

En Panam√°, la empresa de telecomunicaciones Huawei tambi√©n sufri√≥ un duro golpe. La empresa china, criticada por sus v√≠nculos con el ej√©rcito comunista, tuvo que eliminar sus sistemas en 13 ubicaciones estrat√©gicas, que fueron reemplazados con tecnolog√≠a estadounidense.

Costa Rica tambi√©n se mueve con vientos de cambio. La Promotora de Comercio Exterior (PROCOMER) envi√≥ una delegaci√≥n a Taiw√°n para explorar oportunidades de negocio, particularmente en el sector de semiconductores. La Direcci√≥n de Inteligencia y Seguridad (DIS) de Costa Rica tambi√©n particip√≥ en una sesi√≥n de capacitaci√≥n en Taiw√°n. Ambos eventos generaron fuertes quejas diplom√°ticas por parte de China. Costa Rica ha manifestado que la firma china no puede participar en el sector de telecomunicaciones 5G debido a que no es parte del Convenio de Budapest sobre ciberdelincuencia.

Los cambios en Panam√° y Costa Rica no son casuales; son estrat√©gicos. Estas dos naciones son l√≠deres indiscutibles en Centroam√©rica; sus acciones generan un efecto expansivo en toda la regi√≥n.

El efecto Trump ha golpeado la agenda expansiva comunista. China est√° enviando claras se√±ales de presi√≥n y p√°nico, reevaluando, restringiendo y redireccionando muchas de sus inversiones.

content: A poco del vencimiento del plazo para la entrada en vigencia de los nuevos aranceles de Donald Trump, las negociaciones llegar√≠an a buen puerto y habr√≠a un listado que lograr√≠a quedar fuera de la al√≠c ...

Estados Unidos y Argentina habr√≠an llegado a un acuerdo sobre los aranceles que aplicar√° la administraci√≥n de Trump.

resumen:
El presidente estadounidense Donald Trump y la jefa de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, se reunir√°n para discutir sobre comercio, ante el plazo para imponer aranceles altos en las importaciones.

Trump ha amenazado durante meses a la mayor parte del mundo con aranceles elevados con la esperanza de reducir los grandes d√©ficits comerciales de Estados Unidos con muchos socios comerciales clave. La UE no ha sido una excepci√≥n.

Trump dijo que hay ‚Äúun 50-50 de posibilidades, tal vez menos que eso, pero un 50-50 de posibilidades de hacer un acuerdo con la UE‚Äù. Tambi√©n sugiri√≥ que cualquier acuerdo tendr√≠a que ‚Äúreducir‚Äù la tasa arancelaria actualmente programada del 30% sobre el bloque de 27 Estados miembros.

Estados Unidos y la UE parecieron estar cerca de un acuerdo a principios de este mes, pero Trump amenaz√≥ con una tasa arancelaria del 30%. El plazo original de Trump se retras√≥ hasta al menos el viernes.

content: ‚ÄúQueremos tener relaciones diversificadas y no depender de ning√∫n pa√≠s en particular‚Äù, declar√≥ el ex canciller, Celso Amorim.
resumen:
Brasil redoblar√° su apuesta por el BRICS frente a los ataques por parte del actual gobierno estadunidense, dijo al Financial Times el ex canciller brasile√±o Celso Amorim (1993-1994, 2003-2010), hoy en d√≠a asesor internacional del presidente, Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva.

El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, amenaz√≥ el pasado 9 de julio con imponer aranceles de 50 por ciento a los productos brasile√±os a partir de agosto pr√≥ximo, al margen de las tarifas sectoriales, alegando la supuesta persecuci√≥n jur√≠dica que est√° sufriendo el ex mandatario, Jair Bolsonaro (2019-2023), juzgado por intentar un golpe de Estado.

Con anterioridad, Trump afirm√≥ que todos los miembros del BRICS deber√°n pagar un arancel de 10 por ciento por su pertenencia al grupo creado, seg√∫n √©l, para ‚Äúdegenerar‚Äù al d√≥lar estadunidense y en √∫ltima instancia eliminarlo como moneda de reserva.

Para Celso Amorim, esos ataques ‚Äúest√°n reforzando nuestras relaciones con los BRICS, porque queremos tener relaciones diversificadas y no depender de ning√∫n pa√≠s en particular‚Äù.

Los pa√≠ses del BRICS representan 39 por ciento del producto interno bruto mundial y m√°s de 48 por ciento de la poblaci√≥n global.

Brasil ejerce en 2025 la presidencia rotatoria del BRICS y acogi√≥ el 6 y el 7 de julio la XVII cumbre del grupo en la ciudad de R√≠o de Janeiro bajo el lema ‚ÄòFortalecer la cooperaci√≥n del Sur Global para una gobernanza m√°s inclusiva y sostenible‚Äô.

title: El tarifazo de Trump a Brasil
content: Diversos sectores productivos de Brasil se preparan para el impacto del 50% de aranceles desde el 1 de agosto en EEUU, si no se llega a un acuerdo de √∫ltima hora.
resumen:
Diversos sectores productivos de Brasil se preparan para el impacto del 50% de aranceles desde el 1 de agosto en EEUU, si no se llega a un acuerdo de √∫ltima hora.
El presidente estadounidense anunci√≥ aranceles de 50% a los productos brasile√±os desde el 1 de agosto, con el argumento pol√≠tico de que existe una ‚Äúcaza de brujas‚Äù contra el ex presidente Jair Bolsonaro, juzgado por presunto golpismo.
Estados Unidos tiene un super√°vit con Brasil que represent√≥ casi 284 millones de d√≥lares en 2024, seg√∫n cifras oficiales brasile√±as.
Las principales ventas de Brasil al mercado estadounidense son petr√≥leo bruto (12% de sus exportaciones a ese pa√≠s), productos semiterminados de hierro y acero (9,7%), caf√© sin tostar (5,8%) y aeronaves y otros equipamientos (5,2%), entre otros.
Brasil ‚Äìd√©cima econom√≠a mundial, seg√∫n el Fondo Monetario Internacional‚Äì prev√© un impacto considerable para su poderoso sector agropecuario.
Las exportaciones del agronegocio brasile√±o podr√≠an sufrir p√©rdidas por hasta 5.800 millones de d√≥lares, seg√∫n la Confederaci√≥n de Agricultura y Ganader√≠a.
Otros rubros como la aeron√°utica, la pesca y la armament√≠stica destinan m√°s de la mitad de sus exportaciones al mercado estadounidense y podr√≠an sufrir ‚Äúimpactos sobre el nivel de empleo‚Äù, seg√∫n el economista Felipe Salto, ex secretario de Hacienda de S√£o Paulo.
En el caso de la aeron√°utica, el tarifazo puede provocar un ‚Äúajuste de la planta de empleados similar al de la pandemia de Covid-19‚Äù en Embraer, tercera mayor fabricante de aviones del mundo, advirti√≥ la semana pasada su CEO, Francisco Gomes Neto.
Para la empresa brasile√±a, que vende a Estados Unidos el 45% de sus aviones comerciales y el 70% de los ejecutivos, los aranceles de 50% representan ‚Äúcasi un embargo‚Äù.
La perspectiva de aranceles punitivos llev√≥ a la suspensi√≥n preventiva de embarques de carnes, frutas, pescados y granos, seg√∫n entes empresariales.
Unas 77.000 toneladas de frutas est√°n listas en contenedores para su exportaci√≥n a Estados Unidos y esperan una soluci√≥n diplom√°tica para no pudrirse o malvenderse, advirti√≥ la Asociaci√≥n Brasile√±a de los Productores Exportadores de Frutas.
Nuevos embarques de carne bovina hacia Estados Unidos est√°n ‚Äúbajo an√°lisis‚Äù porque solo llegar√≠an luego del 1 de agosto, inform√≥ la Asociaci√≥n Brasile√±a de Carne Vacuna.
Trump ‚Äúno quiere conversar‚Äù, dijo el jueves el presidente de izquierda Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva, quien reitera que su plan A es seguir ‚Äúnegociando‚Äù.
A cargo de buscar un puente con la Casa Blanca, el vicepresidente Geraldo Alckmin asegur√≥ que tuvo d√≠as atr√°s una conversaci√≥n ‚Äúfruct√≠fera‚Äù con el secretario de Comercio estadounidense, Howard Lutnick.
Desde antes de la amenaza de Trump, funcionarios de ambos pa√≠ses manten√≠an contactos t√©cnicos sobre la relaci√≥n comercial, luego de que el republicano impusiera desde abril aranceles del 10%.
La Canciller√≠a brasile√±a inform√≥ que envi√≥ en mayo a Estados Unidos una ‚Äúminuta confidencial de propuesta sobre √°reas de negociaci√≥n‚Äù para explorar ‚Äúsoluciones mutuamente acordadas‚Äù.
A√∫n no hubo respuesta estadounidense, seg√∫n Brasilia.

Mencion√≥ a la Uni√≥n Europea, M√©xico y Canad√° como potenciales socios a trav√©s del Mercosur, pese a los obst√°culos que atraviesa el bloque sudamericano.

‚ÄúHabr√° impactos heterog√©neos: es m√°s f√°cil redirigir la producci√≥n de petr√≥leo o caf√© hacia otros pa√≠ses que la de partes de aeronaves‚Äù, dijo a la AFP el economista Marcos Mendes, del centro de investigaciones Insper.

5.800 millones de d√≥lares podr√≠an perder el sector exportador de Brasil si entran en vigencia los aranceles.

content: ‚ÄúUrsula ha hecho un gran trabajo para la UE, no para nosotros. Si lo logramos, ser√° el mayor acuerdo comercial jam√°s alcanzado‚Äù, declar√≥ la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, que ...
resumen:
‚ÄúUrsula ha hecho un gran trabajo para la UE, no para nosotros. Si lo logramos, ser√° el mayor acuerdo comercial jam√°s alcanzado‚Äù, declar√≥ la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen.

‚ÄúLa UE debe abrir sus mercados a los productos estadounidenses‚Äù, desliz√≥ antes de su reuni√≥n Von der Leyen y anticip√≥ que ese encuentro ‚Äúdurar√° una hora‚Äù.
‚ÄúSabremos en una hora si hay un acuerdo‚Äù, declar√≥.
‚ÄúA√∫n quedan tres o cuatro puntos por discutir, pero se trata de equidad‚Äù, ampli√≥ el magnate y afirm√≥ que no tiene intenci√≥n de reducir los aranceles para la Uni√≥n Europea ‚Äúm√°s all√° del 15%‚Äù.
El sector farmac√©utico no formar√° parte de ning√∫n posible acuerdo entre Estados Unidos y la UE sobre aranceles, declar√≥ Trump.
‚ÄúFundamentalmente, los productos farmac√©uticos no formar√°n parte, porque tenemos que producirlos en Estados Unidos. No podemos estar en una posici√≥n en la que tengamos que depender de otros pa√≠ses‚Äù, sostuvo el republicano.
Y tambi√©n reiter√≥ su llamado a Europa para que ‚Äúsolucione el problema de la inmigraci√≥n r√°pidamente‚Äù.
‚ÄúHar√°n lo mismo que nosotros, as√≠ que m√°s vale que lo hagamos ahora‚Äù, declar√≥ el presidente estadounidense.
‚ÄúHemos trabajado intensamente en el √°mbito de la inmigraci√≥n irregular. La inmigraci√≥n es un reto europeo que requiere una respuesta europea. Como europeos, cumpliremos con nuestras obligaciones internacionales como lo hemos hecho en el pasado. Nosotros, como europeos, decidiremos qui√©n entra en Europa y en qu√© circunstancias, no los traficantes‚Äù, replic√≥ Von der Leyen.
Von der Leyen y el comisario europeo, Maros Sefcovic, ultiman los preparativos para su reuni√≥n en el Turnberry Golf Club, en el suroeste de Escocia.

Por la parte estadounidense, asistir√°n a la reuni√≥n el secretario de Comercio, Howard Lutnick, y el otro negociador jefe, Jamieson Greer.
El borrador del acuerdo ronda el 15%.
M√°s concretamente, el arancel base deber√≠a ser del 14,8%.
Washington aplica actualmente un arancel del 10% ‚Äîimpuesto por Trump durante la suspensi√≥n‚Äî a los productos europeos, al que hay que sumar el 4,8% vigente en la era pre-Trump, de acuerdo con la llamada cl√°usula de la Naci√≥n M√°s Favorecida.

resumen: La reciente decisi√≥n del gobierno de Donald Trump de imponer aranceles de hasta un 50% al caf√© importado, especialmente al proveniente de Brasil, podr√≠a abrir una oportunidad para Honduras, a partir del 1 de agosto pr√≥ximo. Mientras gigantes como Colombia y M√©xico enfrentan aranceles del 10 y 30%, respectivamente, Honduras a√∫n tiene margen para fortalecer su presencia si logra garantizar volumen, trazabilidad y calidad. title: Aranceles de Trump amenazan al caf√© latinoamericano, con precios r√©cord del grano en EE.UU.
content: Los nuevos aranceles de Trump al caf√© afectan precios, exportaciones y competitividad en Latinoam√©rica, reconfigurando el mercado global.
resumen:
El efecto de los aranceles de la Administraci√≥n de Donald Trump al caf√© genera preocupaci√≥n en Latinoam√©rica y podr√≠a forzar a los productores a reconfigurar el mercado global del grano con impactos en los precios, la competitividad y las decisiones de consumo en un contexto de m√°ximos hist√≥ricos en EE.UU. donde la libra supera los 8 d√≥lares.

Brasil, primer productor y exportador global, ser√° el m√°s afectado con el arancel del 50 % que entrar√° en vigor el 1 de agosto sobre sus env√≠os a Estados Unidos. En 2024, el pa√≠s suramericano super√≥ los 2.000 millones de d√≥lares de venta de caf√©, el 16 % de su producci√≥n total y dominando cerca de un tercio del mercado estadounidense. La Asociaci√≥n Brasile√±a de la Industria del Caf√© (ABIC) alert√≥ sobre ¬´impactos extremadamente negativos y relevantes¬ª a toda la cadena productiva, desde los peque√±os caficultores hasta los grandes exportadores. En abril, EE.UU. ya hab√≠a impuesto al pa√≠s un arancel del 10 %. El nuevo gravamen del 50 % amenaza con reducir dr√°sticamente la participaci√≥n del caf√© brasile√±o en su principal destino de exportaci√≥n. El director general del Consejo de Exportadores de Caf√© (Cecaf√©), Marcos Matos, dijo que se estudian mecanismos de negociaci√≥n para lograr que el grano sea considerado un ¬´recurso natural no disponible¬ª en EE.UU. y pueda quedar exento de las tarifas. Matos reconoci√≥ que, si bien Brasil busca diversificar sus ventas hacia Asia y Medio Oriente, el pa√≠s suramericano ¬´es insustituible desde el punto de vista de producci√≥n y exportaci√≥n, as√≠ como Estados Unidos es insustituible para Brasil desde el consumo¬ª.

M√©xico, el d√©cimo productor de caf√© del mundo, enfrenta tambi√©n un escenario complejo si se confirma el arancel del 30 %. Con exportaciones por m√°s de 348 millones de d√≥lares a EE.UU. en 2024, los caficultores de las regiones de Chiapas, Oaxaca y Veracruz temen una ca√≠da de los precios internos si los importadores trasladan el costo del gravamen a la compra local. Ismael G√≥mez Coronel, presidente de la Confederaci√≥n de Cooperativas Unidos para Estar Bien, advirti√≥ que el sector apenas se recupera de una prolongada sequ√≠a, mientras que Jorge Aguilar Reyna, de la Red Maya de Organizaciones de Producci√≥n Org√°nica, se√±al√≥ que las exportaciones de caf√© de especialidad ‚Äîcasi dos millones de sacos anuales‚Äî podr√≠an verse particularmente comprometidas.

Colombia, segundo pa√≠s exportador hacia Estados Unidos despu√©s de Brasil, envi√≥ caf√© por 1.508 millones de d√≥lares en 2024, seg√∫n datos de la ONU. El pa√≠s vive una temporada de producci√≥n r√©cord, con m√°s de 14 millones de sacos entre marzo de 2024 y febrero de 2025, pero enfrenta la amenaza de un arancel del 10 %. Gustavo G√≥mez, director de la Asociaci√≥n Nacional de Exportadores de Caf√© (Asoexport), indic√≥ que el sector ha asumido el arancel base del 10 % vigente desde abril distribuyendo el costo a lo largo de la cadena, pero alerta que el consumidor estadounidense podr√≠a optar por un caf√© m√°s barato en medio de un contexto de inflaci√≥n, afectando directamente la demanda de caf√© premium colombiano.

Per√∫, expuesto a una tarifa del 10 %, tambi√©n sigue con cautela los movimientos arancelarios. En 2024 export√≥ cerca de 3,9 millones de sacos, con EE.UU. como su principal destino (27 % del total, unos 374 millones de d√≥lares), y espera un aumento del 8 % para 2025/2026, hasta 4,2 millones de sacos, seg√∫n datos de la C√°mara del Caf√© y el Cacao.

Honduras mantiene un panorama mixto. Estados Unidos import√≥ 430 millones de d√≥lares de su caf√© en todo 2024 y recibi√≥ el 29 % de sus exportaciones del grano entre octubre de 2024 y julio de 2025, seg√∫n el Instituto Hondure√±o del Caf√© (Ihcaf√©). Miguel Pon, presidente ejecutivo de la Asociaci√≥n de Exportadores de Caf√© de Honduras (ADECAFEH), indica que los nuevos aranceles al caf√© importado podr√≠an tener un impacto ¬´m√°s inmediato¬ª en los consumidores estadounidenses, quienes ver√≠an reflejado el incremento de precios tanto en cafeter√≠as como en supermercados. Las sanciones contra Brasil podr√≠an ¬´abrir una ventana de oportunidad¬ª para Honduras, siempre que el pa√≠s act√∫e con rapidez para ¬´posicionar¬ª una alternativa competitiva en calidad, trazabilidad y vol√∫menes, y que logre negociar condiciones preferenciales con Estados Unidos.

Guatemala, que tambi√©n tendr√° un arancel del 10 %, no est√° entre los diez principales productores de caf√©, pero s√≠ es el quinto pa√≠s que m√°s export√≥ en 2024 a Estados Unidos por un valor de 430 millones de d√≥lares, seg√∫n la ONU.

La guerra arancelaria de Trump reconfigura as√≠ el mapa cafetero latinoamericano, con efectos que apenas comienzan a vislumbrarse mientras varios pa√≠ses intentan negociar antes del 1 de agosto, al tiempo que Brasil, Colombia o Per√∫ buscan reforzar mercados alternativos en Europa y Asia para reducir su dependencia de Estados Unidos.

content: El presidente estadounidense anunci√≥ el marco de un pacto que incluye compras europeas por US$1,35 billones en energ√≠a y defensa, evitando subidas al 30%.
resumen:
EE.UU. y UE alcanzan hist√≥rico acuerdo comercial con aranceles del 15% bajo presi√≥n de Trump.
Donald Trump anunci√≥ este domingo un acuerdo marco con la Uni√≥n Europea que establece aranceles generales del 15% a las importaciones europeas, resolviendo temporalmente una disputa comercial que amenazaba con escalar.
El presidente revel√≥ que la UE acept√≥ comprar US$750.000 millones en energ√≠a estadounidense e invertir US$600.000 millones adicionales, adem√°s de abrirse a importaciones militares.

title: D√≥lar en Colombia: sorpresas en su precio, adem√°s de saltos y desaf√≠os en la √∫ltima semana de julio de 2025

En la √∫ltima semana de julio de 2025, el d√≥lar estadounidense en Colombia se mantiene por encima de los $4.000, mostrando volatilidad. El 25 de julio de 2025, cerr√≥ en un promedio de $4.110,54, con una subida de $47,23 frente a la Tasa Representativa del Mercado (TRM) de $4.063,31. Expertos del Banco Ita√∫ sugieren que el d√≥lar podr√≠a seguir a la baja debido a factores estructurales y c√≠clicos, incluyendo perspectivas fiscales negativas, d√©ficit de cuenta corriente, pol√≠ticas arancelarias err√°ticas, riesgos geopol√≠ticos y cuestionamientos a la Reserva Federal (FED). Pasan los d√≠as y a√∫n no hay claridad sobre c√≥mo quedar√° el arancel de los EE. UU. para los productos que exporta Ecuador. Trump impuso provisionalmente un arancel rec√≠proco de 10 % a todas las naciones, salvo a las que castiga m√°s fuertemente, y plante√≥ que todos los pa√≠ses ten√≠an que negociar aranceles con Washington. El plazo de definici√≥n es ahora agosto 1, y se desconoce si el 10 % es el impuesto m√≠nimo, o si se va a sumar al anterior. Ecuador deber√≠a bregar por que el 10 % no se sume sino que substituya a los aranceles existentes, por ejemplo, rosas de 6,8 % a 10 % y no 16,8 %.

En general, para los productos que nos interesan, el alza arancelaria para Ecuador ser√≠a inferior que aquella para nuestros competidores. Ser√≠a el caso del camar√≥n, at√∫n y cacao. En banano no habr√≠a mayor efecto, pero las rosas ser√≠an m√°s vulnerables.

Camar√≥n: el c√°lculo es complicado porque para proteger a la flota camaronera, EE. UU. impone dos tipos de recargos que pueden variar de empresa a empresa, pero que es posible conseguir su eliminaci√≥n. Sumando el 10 % del arancel rec√≠proco, el camar√≥n nacional pagar√≠a un arancel m√°s recargo de 24 % en promedio, similar al de Indonesia (23 %). Ecuador estar√≠a en ventaja frente a otros proveedores. Para la India, que tiene el 38 % del mercado, el arancel m√°s recargos ser√≠a 30 %. Pero es posible que la India consiga una reducci√≥n del arancel. Los otros competidores tendr√≠an una carga arancelaria incluso mayor: Tailandia (37 %) y Vietnam (61 %).

At√∫n enlatado en agua. Ahora el arancel subir√≠a a 22 %, pero como Trump est√° gravando alto productos del sudeste de Asia, estos pagar√≠an m√°s: Tailandia, el mayor proveedor, 48 %; Vietnam, Filipinas e Indonesia, 31-32 %. M√©xico podr√≠a cabildear para entrar con 0 % arancel.

Cacao: todos los proveedores importantes de EE. UU. tendr√≠an el arancel rec√≠proco de 10 %, excepto Costa de Marfil, el mayor exportador mundial y principal proveedor de EE. UU., con el 21 %. Lo que podr√≠an aprovechar Ecuador y Ghana, segundo y tercer abastecedor.

Banano: de 0 % pasamos a 10 %. Pero igual el banano de pa√≠ses centroamericanos y Colombia con que competimos a pesar que todos ellos tienen acuerdos comerciales. Pero se entiende que a M√©xico no se le recargar√° ese 10 % debido a su acuerdo comercial, lo que llevar√≠a a M√©xico a importar banano centroamericano para su consumo interno y destinar el suyo para exportar a EE. UU. M√©xico hoy suministra aproximadamente el 7 % del banano importado por EE. UU. Si M√©xico incrementa su producci√≥n, afectar√≠a la exportaci√≥n de los dem√°s, incluyendo Ecuador.

Rosas: el arancel para Ecuador y Colombia subir√≠a 10 %: a Colombia a 10 % y a Ecuador a 16,8 %. Pero M√©xico podr√≠a convertirse en competidor gracias a 0 % de arancel.

title: Trump touts ‚Äòbiggest deal ever made‚Äô as US and EU sketch trade framework
content: President Donald Trump announced Sunday that the United States and the European Union reached a framework for a trade deal, ending a monthslong saga with America‚Äôs largest trading partner.

title: Trump‚Äôs latest clumsy deal has unintended consequences
content: The threat of a full-scale trans-Atlantic trade war has been averted with a deal between the US and the EU, but there is some confusion over just what has been agreed to.
resumen: A deal was struck between the US and European Union, averting a trans-Atlantic trade war. Both sides have differing interpretations of what they‚Äôve agreed to. The deal imposes a baseline tariff of 15 per cent on all EU exports to the US. Before Trump regained office, the average tariff on EU exports was 2.5 per cent. Ursula von der Leyen said the new rate would apply to European cars, pharmaceuticals and semiconductors, while Donald Trump said pharmaceuticals were ‚Äúunrelated to this deal‚Äù. The US has separate investigations of pharmaceuticals and semiconductors under way that could lead to sectoral tariffs on imports of those products. Trump said the new baseline tariff was in exchange for the EU ‚Äúopening up their countries at zero tariff‚Äù, whereas the EU says the agreement for ‚Äúzero for zero‚Äù tariffs relates to certain strategic products and their parts, such as chemicals, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products. The deal has been described as a ‚Äúroad map‚Äù for a detailed agreement rather than a conventional trade deal. The agreement would also have to be ratified by the European Parliament and the 27 individual national parliaments of the EU‚Äôs members before it could take effect. The deal envisages the EU buying a lot of US energy ‚Äì $US750 billion ($1.14 trillion) of energy over the next three years, as well as weaponry. Trump also said the EU would invest $US600 billion in the US. The EU now imports about half its LNG from the US. The deals have unintended consequences for American companies, consumers and the US economy. The promise to invest $US600 billion in the US was vague. The investment agreement with the EU appears just a broad statement of intent. The Japanese have agreed to provide equity, loans and loan guarantees for investments in the US. Trump said Japan would invest, ‚Äúat my discretion‚Äù, the $US550 billion. The presentation card on Trump‚Äôs desk originally said Japan would invest $US400 billion, but the ‚Äú$400B‚Äù was crossed out and altered to $US500 billion. When Trump announced the detail, it had suddenly become $US550 billion. The 15 per cent tariff on European vehicle and vehicle part exports is a big win for the Europeans. Thanks to Trump, who has imposed 25 per cent duties on imports of steel, aluminium, vehicle parts and those components of US vehicles not made within the US, the European and Japanese companies will have a material competitive advantage over America‚Äôs own carmakers.

title: Trump's Trade Deals Won't End the Harm Caused by His Tariffs
content: All told Trump's IEEPA tariffs are expected to impose some $1.9 trillion in tax increases on Americans over the next decade, costing the average household some $1000 per year, while also raising ...
resumen: Trump has reached trade deals with the European Union, the UK, Japan, Vietnam, and the Philippines. In each case, tariff rates under the deals are vastly higher than they were before Trump started his trade war. The new tariff on most EU goods will be 15%, compared to an average rate of 1.47% before Trump's second term (the EU imposed an average %1.35 rate on US imports). It's a similar story with Japan (15% vs. 2%), Britain (10% vs. 3.3%), and the others. Under the Administration's interpretation of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA), Trump would retain unfettered discretion to raise tariffs further any time he wants for any reason. Trump's IEEPA tariffs are expected to impose some $1.9 trillion in tax increases on Americans over the next decade, costing the average household some $1000 per year. The relatively modest reductions in tariffs against US exports these deals include (e.g. Britain reduced its tariffs from an average of 3.8% to 1.8%) don't even begin to offset the enormous harm. The Liberty Justice Center and I secured a ruling against the "Liberation Day" tariffs in the US Court of International Trade, and our case (together with one filed by 12 state governments) is now on appeal in the Federal Circuit.

title: Here's a puzzling question: Why are stocks at record highs despite looming tariffs?
content: President Trump's tariffs could hit the economy badly and lead to higher inflation. But Wall Street investors are reacting by sending stocks to record highs.
resumen:
President Trump's tariffs could hit the economy badly and lead to higher inflation. Wall Street investors are reacting by sending stocks to record highs.

The S&P 500 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq have hit a recent string of record highs.

The economy has held up much better than many expected. Inflation ticked up to 2.7% in June from a year earlier. The unemployment rate is still at a historically low rate of 4.1%.

Brad Peterson, national portfolio adviser at Northern Trust, says the economy has proven to be more resilient than many feared in the face of tariff threats.

The U.S. economy is expected to grow at a slower pace in the second half of the year than in 2024, with the chance of a recession seen at 33% in the next 12 months, according to the latest quarterly survey from The Wall Street Journal.

Corporate earnings are proving sturdier than what many in the markets had initially feared.

Companies such as Alphabet (the parent company of Google), Netflix, AT&T and Hasbro beat Wall Street expectations.

Delta Air Lines said travelers are feeling more confident despite the tariff uncertainty.

Amanda Agati, the chief investment officer for PNC Asset Management Group in Philadelphia, says "We may feel bad. We may feel concerned, but the hard data would suggest our behavior is something else entirely".

General Motors announced a $1.1 billion hit to its profit because of higher tariffs.

Kevin Gordon, a senior investment strategist at the Schwab Center for Financial Research in New York, says small businesses struggle a lot more from higher tariffs because they just don't have the kind of flexibility or the cash balances that large companies do to be able to combat it.

When Trump first announced his round of tariffs in early April, stocks took a nosedive. Stocks rebounded sharply after Trump then announced a 90-day pause ‚Äî which has now been extended a second time to Friday. The president did retain the baseline 10% tariff on just about everything the U.S. imports, while imposing other tariffs on some items such as steel and aluminum.

Trump announced a trade deal with Japan, saying the U.S. will impose a 15% tariff on imports from Asia's second-largest economy.

The new tariff helped send the S&P 500 to yet another record high.

Trinh Nguyen, senior economist for emerging Asia at Natixis, posted on X, "We live in a new normal where 10% is the new zero and so 15% and 20% doesn't seem so bad if everyone else got it".

The average tariff rate is still at the highest it has been since the 1930s.

Sandy Villere, a partner and portfolio manager at Villere & Co. in New Orleans, says markets could fall by 10% to 12% from current levels in the second half of the year.

title: US Fed poised to defy Trump on interest rate cuts
content: The US central bank is widely expected to hold off slashing interest rates again at its upcoming meeting, as officials gather under the cloud of an intensifying pressure campaign by US President ...
resumen: The US central bank is widely expected to hold off slashing interest rates again at its upcoming meeting. Policymakers at the independent US Federal Reserve have kept the benchmark lending rate steady since the start of the year. The bank meets tomorrow and Wednesday. The Fed seeks a balance between reining in inflation and the health of the jobs market. The Fed‚Äôs benchmark lending rate stands at a range between 4.25 percent and 4.50 percent. US President Donald Trump has repeatedly criticized Fed Chair Jerome Powell for not slashing rates further, calling him a ‚Äúnumbskull‚Äù and ‚Äúmoron.‚Äù Trump signaled he could use the Fed‚Äôs US$2.5 billion renovation project as an avenue to oust Powell. Trump visited the Fed construction site on Thursday last week, making a tense appearance with Powell. Economists expect the Fed to look past the political pressure at its policy meeting. Oxford Economics chief US economist Ryan Sweet said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre just now beginning to see the evidence of tariffs‚Äô impact on inflation.‚Äù Powell‚Äôs term as Fed chair ends in May next year. Fed Governor Christopher Waller and Vice Chair for Supervision Michelle Bowman have both signaled openness to rate cuts early this month. Nationwide chief economist Kathy Bostjancic said too many dissents could be ‚Äúeyebrow-raising.‚Äù

title: Tariffs aren't good news but it could have been much worse
content: While the crucial EU-US trade deal announced this weekend does bring certainty for businesses, there are significant drawbacks.
resumen: The crucial US EU trade deal announced this weekend brings certainty for businesses, but there are significant drawbacks. Tariffs are negative for trade. The US is a significant export market for Ireland, and many sectors now face duties of 15% which did not exist last year. The biggest issue is pharmaceuticals, which are the largest Irish export to the US, valued at ‚Ç¨44bn in 2024. US President Donald Trump had threatened enormous duties on drugs imported by America and ordered a national security investigation of the pharmaceutical sector. T√°naiste Simon Harris said his understanding was that after the investigation concludes the maximum tariff which could be imposed would be 15%. Pharmaceuticals made in Ireland may well face 15% tariffs in future, up from zero at present. A decision on tariffs on spirits is critically important to Ireland's whiskey industry. Another key sector for Ireland is the manufacture of computer chips. It has been subject to a separate investigation by the Trump administration and faced the possibility of punitive tariffs, but it too could face a 15% tariff after the investigation ends. European Commission President Ursula Von Der Leyen said there was no decision yet regarding spirits exported to the US. This is critically important to Ireland's whiskey industry which has already seen several recent closures. There had been speculation that sector could have been part of a zero-for-zero tariff arrangement, but that is not yet agreed. Another important area for Ireland is aircraft leasing. Ms Von Der Leyen said last night that aviation would be part of a tariff-free arrangement. For other EU countries the massive duty of 27.5% which was imposed on European cars now falls to 15%. Some existing tariffs will be folded into that baseline 15%, meaning it would be an all-in tariff. It is expected to include the existing "most favoured nation" duties of 4.8% which exist currently under World Trade Organization rules. The fact there is a deal at all avoids the threat of a prolonged tit-for-tat trade war. It means businesses can plan, investments can be made, and job-creating projects can proceed. Exporters are already seeking Government support as they navigate the new reality of the Trump administration‚Äôs tariffs. The EU-US agreement is not a trade deal in the usual sense. What was announced yesterday was the framework of a deal with much detail yet to be finalised. Yesterday wasn‚Äôt the end of the negotiations, but it was a milestone.

title: Nvidia AI Chips $1 Billion Smuggled to China Despite Trump Export Controls
content: B in Nvidia AI chips reportedly smuggled to China despite Trump export controls, raising questions about efficacy of US sanctions on tech ...
resumen:
Despite the Trump administration‚Äôs stricter export controls on advanced semiconductor technology, at least $1 billion worth of advanced AI chips of Nvidia found their way to China through sophisticated networks of smugglers within three months of the controls.

The prohibited chips‚Äìsuch as Nvidia‚Äôs top-of-the-line B200, H100, and H200 models‚Äìare the exact same chips used by the world‚Äôs most sophisticated artificial intelligence systems on the planet today.

The smuggling networks coordinated whole server racks of the illicit processors and had them sent directly to Chinese data centers.

By May 2025, Chinese vendors started openly marketing these prohibited chips to AI-oriented data center operators.

Industry experts estimated the number of such prohibited Nvidia chips to be between 10,000 and hundreds of thousands that found their way into China in 2024 alone.

Singaporean authorities arrested people involved in suspected theft of $390 million servers that were ultimately bound for China.

Nvidia claimed that it is technically difficult and economically unviable to build data centers using smuggled chips, as Nvidia only offers service and support for products sold through official channels.

The Trump administration and U.S. Commerce Department put numbers to the extent of the issue and took steps to investigate new legislation aimed at improving AI chip tracing.

In July 2025, Trump issued a license to allow Nvidia to resume selling some chips namely the H20 model to China.

Nvidia‚Äôs China business generated $17 billion in revenue last fiscal year nearly 13% of the company‚Äôs overall revenue.

title: Trump sets EU tariff at 15%, lower than his original threat, after meeting in Scotland
content: Trump had most recently threatened tariffs of 30% on imports from the European Union. But on Sunday, he met with the president of the European Commission, and they agreed to a lower level.
resumen:
President Trump announced a trade deal with the European Union on Sunday after meeting with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen at his golf course in Scotland.

Under the agreement, most EU exports to the United States will face a 15% tariff, down from the 30% tariff that Trump had most recently threatened. The EU has agreed to accept U.S. imports without tariffs.

Steel, aluminum, and pharmaceuticals will not be included in the deal.

The EU agreed to buy $750 billion worth of U.S. energy as part of the agreement, and to invest $600 billion into the United States, according to Trump.

Trump met with Ursula von der Leyen on July 27, 2025, at his golf resort in Turnberry, Scotland.

title: Increase this week in Trump's Mexico tariffs could strain Texas economy
content: The possibility of a 30% tariff this week ‚Äúis a game changer,‚Äù said Dante Galeazzi, CEO and president of the Texas International Produce ...
resumen:
Importers and exporters based in Texas have so far avoided the harshest effects of the trade war sparked by President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs on imports from a host of countries, but they could be in for a rude awakening this week.

Mexico, which is Texas‚Äô largest trading partner, has been largely exempt from tariffs due to a March agreement that allowed an estimated 85% to 90% of all Mexican goods to avoid the 25% tariff the Trump administration placed on its imports.

Trump this month told Mexico, two dozen other countries and the European Union that their exports will face an increase of the tax on their goods unless they quickly negotiate new trade deals with the U.S. Trump‚Äôs letter to Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum promises to raise the rate against the country to 30% on Aug. 1 and makes no mention of extending the spring agreement exempting most Mexican imports.

Dante Galeazzi, CEO and president of the Texas International Produce Association, said, ‚ÄúWhen we talk about the possibility of a 30% tariff, that is a game changer.‚Äù His organization represents 400 Texas companies throughout the produce supply chain that grow or import $13 billion worth of produce annually.

Two-way trade between the U.S. and Mexico totaled $840 billion last year. Texas traded a total of $281 billion with Mexico in 2024, according to the Office of the United States Trade Representative.

The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement, negotiated by the three countries during Trump‚Äôs first term, aimed to eliminate trade barriers and level the playing field between the three countries‚Äô labor and manufacturing sectors.

In March, two months into Trump‚Äôs second term, U.S. trade policy with its two biggest trading partners has see-sawed dramatically, briefly putting in place a 25% tariff on Mexican and Canadian goods before a deal was announced two days later to exempt all USMCA-compliant goods from the tariff.

Craig Slate, CEO and president of Arizona-based Mexican produce importer SunFed, which operates in Texas, said, ‚ÄúBack in March was super difficult, super stressful, lots of preparation getting ready for it.‚Äù

Trump cited the flow of fentanyl across both the northern and southern borders as the basis for the tariffs in March. Mexico and Canada promised retaliatory tariffs. Then, the deal was announced to exempt most goods traded between the three countries from the tariffs for 30 days and later extended a further 90 days in April.

Economists fear the economy could again face difficulties like those seen in March because the tariff rate for most trade in North America could effectively jump from 0% to 30% if the USMCA exemptions are not kept in place.

Ed Hirs, an economist and energy fellow at the University of Houston, said, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going to be devastating to U.S.-Mexico trade.‚Äù

For SunFed, the effect of the jump in tariffs could be painful, Slate said. SunFed is the company that pays the tariff to the U.S. government on its imported goods, which includes watermelons, squash, bell peppers, cucumbers and cantaloupe.

Slate said he believes it‚Äôs more likely they will see shortages of certain products in the future because farmers or importers will decide it‚Äôs not worth the financial risk of importing products to the U.S.

A 50% tariff on aluminum and steel in place since early June is driving a ‚Äúnotable pickup‚Äù in cost in Texas‚Äô manufacturing sector, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas‚Äô July report on the health of the region‚Äôs economy.

Trump announced a 50% tariff on copper that will go into effect on Aug. 1, which is expected to further increase manufacturing costs, Hirs said.

U.S. Rep. Tony Gonzales, R-San Antonio, said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm very focused on the Aug. 1 date. What that means is President Trump has given us a couple weeks to try to come up with a solution, and I‚Äôve seen Mexico ‚Ä¶ change, from months ago basically being allowed to do whatever they want to ‚Ä¶ all of the sudden, they‚Äôre coming to the table.‚Äù

Glenn Hamer, president and CEO of the Texas Association of Business, cited Texas‚Äô status as the eighth-largest economy in the world.

A spokesperson for Gov. Greg Abbott said the trade war is an opportunity to ‚Äúreset‚Äù global supply chains.

Hamer, trade war opponents and Texas businesses also say a 30% tariff on goods currently covered by the USMCA could be difficult for the Texas economy.

Galeazzi said, ‚ÄúWe learned firsthand and painfully during COVID that once you disrupt the supply chain, it never returns to exactly how it was.‚Äù

Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney on Tuesday downplayed the possibility of that happening.

Sheinbaum said on July 12, ‚ÄúWe believe ‚Ä¶ we are going to reach an agreement with the United States government and, of course, achieve better terms.‚Äù

Hamer said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôd like to see predictability and stability in our tariff policy as soon as possible.‚Äù

content: Von der Leyen, por su parte, remarc√≥ que EE.UU. y la UE "son las mayores econom√≠as del mundo", con un volumen comercial de 1,7 billones de d√≥lares, y reconoci√≥ que se trata de "reequilibrar" la relaci ...
resumen:
El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, reafirm√≥ que ve "un 50 % de probabilidad" de alcanzar un acuerdo arancelario con la Uni√≥n Europea, pero se√±al√≥ que "la falta de equidad" supuestamente por parte de Bruselas es uno de los obst√°culos para conseguirlo.

Trump hizo estas declaraciones al inicio de su reuni√≥n en su complejo de golf de Turnberry, en el oeste de Escocia, con la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von de Leyen, quien por su parte confi√≥ en cerrar el que ser√≠a "el mayo acuerdo del mundo".

"Si no llegamos a un pacto, habr√° aranceles", afirm√≥ el l√≠der republicano, en alusi√≥n a su amenaza de aplicar unilateralmente tarifas fijas del 30 % a las importaciones comunitarias a partir del 1 de agosto.

Von der Leyen, por su parte, remarc√≥ que EE.UU. y la UE "son las mayores econom√≠as del mundo", con un volumen comercial de 1,7 billones de d√≥lares, y reconoci√≥ que se trata de "reequilibrar" la relaci√≥n bilateral dado que Estados Unidos tiene un d√©ficit comercial con los Veintisiete.

Trump tambi√©n rechaz√≥ que su Administraci√≥n est√© dispuesta a ofrecer menos de un 15 % de aranceles al bloque comunitario, que es el porcentaje que, seg√∫n fuentes de la negociaci√≥n, se estar√≠a pactando como soluci√≥n de compromiso para evitar una guerra comercial por ambas partes a partir de agosto.

Aunque la intenci√≥n es colaborativa, Von der Leyen llega a la cita respaldada por un paquete de contramedidas de represalia por valor de 93,000 millones de euros, que se aplicar√≠an de forma escalonada si no hay entendimiento.

title: EU-US Trade Pact Halves Tariffs, Avoids Trade War
content: The United States and European Union reached a significant trade agreement that slashed tariffs on EU goods to 15%, avoiding a larger trade conflict. The deal promises EU investments in the U.S. and ...
resumen: The United States and European Union reached a trade agreement that slashed tariffs on EU goods to 15%, avoiding a larger trade conflict. The deal promises EU investments in the U.S. and increased purchases of U.S. energy and arms. The agreement stabilizes trade relations and benefits both economies. The United States and the European Union have agreed on a trade framework, cutting import tariffs on EU goods to 15%, averting a major trade war. This agreement, announced by U.S. President Donald Trump and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen, is said to strengthen the trans-Atlantic economic ties. President Trump described the deal as historic, highlighting plans for the EU to significantly invest and purchase U.S. energy and military equipment. Despite some concerns over the tariffs' rate, the agreement is viewed favorably by many, including German Chancellor Friedrich Merz, as it avoids a potential trade conflict. However, there are criticisms regarding the deal's high-level nature and tariff imbalances. While it secures tariffs on key sectors like semiconductors and pharmaceuticals, questions remain, particularly concerning the impact on U.S.‚ÄìEU spirits trade and existing steel and aluminum tariffs. Nevertheless, officials from both sides believe the agreement fosters stability and predictability in global trade.

title: The Risk Of Rushing: Details Murky On Trump, Van Der Leyen Trade Deal
content: United States, European Union stave off 30% U.S. tariffs on imports, due to start on Friday, at least for now. But what about pharmaceuticals?
resumen:
President Trump and European Union President Ursula von der Leyen shook hands on a deal Sunday to stave off 30% tariffs on U.S. imports from the E.U., though it remains unclear what the deal is.

It appears that most if not all U.S. imports from the European Union will face a 15% tariff.

It also appears that most U.S. exports to the 27 nations of the European Union will not have a tariff.

The 15% tariff on U.S. imports is up slightly from the 10% ‚Äúbaseline‚Äù tariff already in place with all countries of the world since Trump began the global trade war to reduce the U.S. deficit.

The ‚Äúdeal‚Äù would seem to lower the 25% tariff in place on passenger vehicle imports into the United States.

The zero tariff rate would replace a rate of 2.8% on the U.S. export side.

A spokesperson for the European Union would not respond to a ‚Äúrequest for comment about Trump‚Äôs claim."

Does the 15% tariff on E.U. imports include critical medicines and the compounds used to make those medicines, imports into the United States that Ireland and other European nations dominate?

President Trump says no, according to one news source.

‚ÄúWe have 15% for pharmaceuticals,‚Äù Von der Leyen said, according to another.

The United States‚Äô top 15 trade partners, which account for 44.40% of all U.S. trade, including 44.22% of all U.S. exports and 44.51% of all imports, includes the following seven European Union nations:

No. 4 Germany,
No. 6 Switzerland,
No. 7. Ireland,
No. 11 United Kingdom,
No. 13 the Netherlands,
No. 14 France,
No. 15 Italy.

The trade with just these European Union nations is relatively balanced, with those seven accounting for 21.38% of all U.S. trade, including 20.27% of all exports and 22.05% of all U.S. imports. The overall deficit with these five nations is $149.61 billion.

The European Union is accounting for 20.22% of all U.S. imports and 18.57% of all U.S. exports through May, the latest data available from the U.S. Census Bureau.

Six of the 10 U.S. imports from the European Union where the E.U. was a dominant source were in the area of pharmaceuticals and with chemical compounds used to make medicines in this country. The same six in 10 statistic is true of U.S. exports to the 27-nation European Union.

99.22% of $42.95 billion in U.S. imports in the insulin, hormone and steroid category (HS code 2937) through May were from the European Union, with 98.48% coming from Ireland. It is the top U.S. import from the European Union this year.

The same category is a top U.S. export to the European Union, accounting for 53.85% of the $4.94 billion in U.S. exports to the world, ranking fourth overall to the European Union.

The European Union is responsible for 79.77% of the $2.97 billion in wine imports into the United States through May and 80.78% of $2.15 billion in perfumes.

Passenger vehicles (HS code 8703), with a 19.80% of the $81.07 billion total.

Jet engines and parts (HS code 8411), with 37.86% of the $13.06 billion in U.S. imports from the European Union.

Medical instruments (HS code 9018), which includes everything from needles and catheters to MRI machines and parts, with 24.87% of the $18.57 billion total from the European Union.

Artificial knee, hip joints and other body parts (HS code 9021), with 51.64% of the total $8.06 billion imported from the world through May coming from the European Union.

The European Union has an appetite for the broad nut category (HS code 0802) that is dominated by shelled almonds and pistachios in the shell, with 37.49% of the $4.09 billion total in U.S. exports through May headed to the European Union. In addition, the E.U. has a thirst for the alcoholic spirits category (HS code 2208) that is dominated by bourbon and whiskey, with 46.66% of the total $1.08 billion sent to the world.

The European Union would be buying $750 billion in U.S. energy products.

In 2024, U.S. exports to the world of oil, gasoline and other refined petroleum products, and natural gas such as LNG ‚Äì the dominant categories ‚Äì was less than $300 billion.

Oil (HS code 2709), with 36.62% of the total $43.21 billion in U.S. exports to the world headed to the European Union through May. This is the top U.S. export to the European Union.

Petroleum gas, which includes liquid natural gas, or LNG (HS code 2711), with 37.37% of the total $35.56 billion in U.S. shipments to the world. This is the third-ranked U.S. export to the European Union through May.

Passenger vehicles (HS code 8703), with 21.09% of the $22.42 billion in exports to the world sent to the nations of the European Union. This is the No. 8-ranked U.S. export there this year.

title: Trump Administration Live Updates: Preliminary E.U. Trade Deal Reached After Months of Tense Talks
content: The deal, which would set a 15 percent tariff on most E.U. goods, averted what could have become a painful trade war with the United States‚Äô biggest source of imports. ‚ÄúWe are agreeing that the tariff ...
resumen: The European Union and the United States agreed on Sunday to a broad-brush trade deal that sets a 15 percent tariff on most E.U. goods, including cars and pharmaceuticals. The deal sets a 15 percent tariff on European goods imported to the U.S. The United States and the European Union also agreed to drop tariffs to zero on a range of goods, including aircraft, plane parts, certain chemicals, certain generic drugs, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products. President Trump said that the European Union had agreed to purchase $750 billion of American energy, which Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the E.U.‚Äôs executive branch, said would be spread out over three years. The 27-nation bloc also agreed to increase its investment in the United States by more than $600 billion above current levels, Mr. Trump said, adding that the European Union would buy military equipment. A senior U.S. official said that those investments would include pharmaceuticals and the automotive industry, among others. The two sides also agreed to drop tariffs to zero on a range of goods, including aircraft, plane parts, certain chemicals, certain generic drugs, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products, Ms. von der Leyen said. The 15 percent tariff rate given to Europe mirrors the main tariff rate of the U.S.-Japanese trade agreement that was announced last Tuesday. A senior U.S. official said the 50 percent tariff the Trump administration had imposed on steel and aluminum globally was not part of the deal. The U.S. official added that European pharmaceutical and semiconductor exports will be subject to a 15 percent tariff. The administration is currently preparing an investigation that will apply tariffs to those sectors globally, which the official said could come in two or three weeks. Pharmaceuticals are Europe‚Äôs most important export to the United States. Ms. von der Leyen said that no decisions had been made yet on whether wine and spirits would be exempt. The European Union last year accounted for nearly $610 billion of the $3.3 trillion in goods imported by the United States. The European Union also agreed to purchase $750 billion of American energy. The bloc also agreed to increase its investment in the United States by more than $600 billion.

title: U.S. Reaches Preliminary Trade Deal With Europe
content: The United States and the European Union agreed to a 15 percent base tariff after weeks of negotiations, which were among the Trump administration‚Äôs most difficult discussions.
resumen:
The European Union and the United States agreed on Sunday to a broad-brush trade deal that sets a 15 percent tariff on most E.U. goods, including cars and pharmaceuticals.

President Trump said that the European Union had agreed to purchase $750 billion of American energy, which Ursula von der Leyen, the president of the E.U.‚Äôs executive branch, told reporters would be spread out over three years.

The 27-nation bloc also agreed to increase its investment in the United States by more than $600 billion above current levels, Mr. Trump said, adding that the European Union would buy military equipment. A senior U.S. official said that those investments would include pharmaceuticals and the automotive industry, among others.

The two sides also agreed to drop tariffs to zero on a range of goods, including aircraft, plane parts, certain chemicals, certain generic drugs, semiconductor equipment and some agricultural products, Ms. von der Leyen said.

A senior U.S. official said the 50 percent tariff the Trump administration had imposed on steel and aluminum globally was not part of the deal.

The U.S. official added that European pharmaceutical and semiconductor exports will be subject to a 15 percent tariff.

Ms. von der Leyen said that no decisions had been made yet on whether wine and spirits would be exempt.

The European Union last year accounted for nearly $610 billion of the $3.3 trillion in goods imported by the United States.

The 15 percent tariff rate given to Europe mirrors the main tariff rate of the U.S.-Japanese trade agreement that was announced last Tuesday, and is lower than the 19 and 20 percent rates imposed on several Southeast Asian countries. But it is higher than the 10 percent tax that Europeans had been angling for, and that Mr. Trump applied to British goods.

According to the World Trade Organization, before Mr. Trump came into office, the trade-weighted tariff the United States charged on foreign goods was 2.2 percent, while the European Union‚Äôs was 2.7 percent.

Mr. Trump imposed a 25 percent tariff on foreign cars and car parts in April. European automakers, which sent cars worth 38.5 billion euros ($45 billion) to the United States last year.

Mr. Trump also lowered the tariff rate on Japanese auto exports to 15 percent as part of the deal announced last week.

title: Japan‚Äôs post-upper-house election crisis
content: The LDP‚Äôs poor upper house result compounds uncertainty at a time when Japan‚Äôs quiet leadership is critical for regional stability and the defence of the multilateral project.
resumen:
Japan‚Äôs ruling Liberal Democratic Party and its coalition partner Komeito suffered a decisive defeat in the July 2025 upper house election, failing to win a majority for the second consecutive election. Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is set to resign by the end of August following overwhelming pressure from within his own party, leaving the LDP fractured. The incoming prime minister will inherit a weakened party struggling with corruption scandals while navigating difficult negotiations with opposition parties to form a government. Japan must also manage unpredictable trade relations with the Trump administration, including a costly tariff deal that offers no guarantee of long-term stability.

Japan‚Äôs ruling Liberal Democratic Party and its junior coalition partner Komeito failed to win a majority for the second election in a row. After the upper house election on 20 July, the government is now in the minority in both houses of parliament. Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba is reportedly set to resign by the end of August. If he does, whoever replaces Ishiba will face formidable challenges to unite the LDP; navigate tricky negotiations with opposition parties; regain Japanese public trust; boost economic growth; and manage alliance relations with the ever-erratic Donald Trump.

The election loss has exposed the LDP‚Äôs political weakness. Of the 125 seats up for election, the LDP won just 39, a loss of 13 seats. With Komeito‚Äôs eight seats, the ruling coalition won just 47 seats. Counting those upper house seats not contested during this election cycle, the LDP‚ÄìKomeito coalition has 122 to 126 scattered among opposition parties.

Ishiba‚Äôs position appears to be untenable. While he initially expressed his intention to stay on as the country‚Äôs leader in the immediate aftermath of the election, dissent within his own party has forced his hand. On 23 July, the Mainichi Shimbun reported that he would resign by the end of August after he concluded an agreement in the trade war with the United States. Another reason for his delayed exit may be to buy time to coordinate voting on who would replace him as prime minister.

LDP opposition to Ishiba in the wake of the election moved beyond the usual suspects of his intra-party rivals. Criticism from the arch-conservative Sanae Takaichi, whom Ishiba defeated in the LDP leadership election in September 2024, and members of the former Shinzo Abe faction who are backing her, was to be expected. Calls from junior LDP backbenchers for Ishiba to resign, a number of LDP prefectural branches, as well as a tap on the shoulder in a rare meeting with three former LDP prime ministers ‚Äî Taro Aso, Yoshihide Suga and Fumio Kishida ‚Äî on 23 July made pressures for his resignation all but insurmountable.

Once Ishiba resigns as prime minister and leader of the LDP, two separate leadership selection processes will be triggered. First, the LDP will decide on a new leader. Based on the September 2024 party leadership contest won by Ishiba, the contest will boil down once again to two candidates: one backed by the conservative nationalists in the Aso faction and the former Abe faction; and a reformist candidate backed by party elder statesmen like former prime ministers Fumio Kishida and Yoshihide Suga seeking to reinvent the LDP and regain popular support in the wake of the Unification Church and slush fund scandals that kickstarted the LDP‚Äôs recent decline. Second, the parliament will vote to select a new prime minister. If no candidate secures a majority in the first round of voting in the lower house, a runoff between the top two candidates would determine the outcome. This scenario may force the LDP to make policy concessions to opposition parties willing to support their candidate, such as those that Ishiba negotiated with the Democratic Party for the People (DPFP). The divided opposition parties ‚Äî spanning the political spectrum from the Japan Communist Party, the centre-left Constitutional Democratic Party (CDP), the centrist-technocratic DPFP, the neo-liberal Japan Innovation Party and the far-right conspiracist Sanseito ‚Äî have historically struggled to coordinate effectively, meaning that a new LDP prime minister is the most likely outcome despite the party‚Äôs bruising electoral defeat.

The new prime minister must then restore unity within a fractured LDP and regain public trust. The party remains split over how to address the twin crises that triggered its decline: the Unification Church scandal that exposed decades of mutually beneficial arrangements between LDP politicians and the controversial religious organisation, and the political slush fund scandal that revealed systemic campaign finance violations mostly by the former Abe faction. The party‚Äôs conservative nationalists, particularly those aligned with the former Abe faction, remain resistant to detailed public accounting that might implicate longtime power brokers, while reformist elements see an opportunity to sideline the national conservatives as the true centre of power in the party.

Adding to these challenges is the emergence of the right-wing nationalist Sanseito, as a significant political force that threatens to further erode the LDP‚Äôs support base. The party, which began as a YouTube channel during the COVID-19 pandemic, achieved stunning gains in the July 2025 upper house election, winning 14 seats ‚Äî a dramatic surge from its previous single seat. Campaigning under the slogan ‚ÄòJapanese First‚Äô, Sanseito successfully attracted disaffected conservative nationalist voters who had traditionally supported the LDP, capitalising on frustrations over rising living costs, immigration concerns, and what party leader Sohei Kamiya characterised as a ‚Äòsilent invasion‚Äô of foreigners.

Sanseito‚Äôs social media-driven success poses a dilemma for the LDP: whether to adopt some of its populist rhetoric and conspiracy-tinged messaging to win back voters, or risk further haemorrhaging support to a party that has proven adept at channelling anti-establishment sentiment. Any temptation to embrace Sanseito‚Äôs xenophobic appeals or conspiracist style could further damage the LDP‚Äôs credibility with moderate voters and international partners. But ignoring the underlying grievances that Sanseito has tapped into may also prove costly.

The Trump playbook creates immediate challenges for an incoming prime minister, who must find ways to deal with Japan‚Äôs cost-of-living crisis, including negotiating a tariff deal with the White House. Trump announced a new deal that would reduce tariffs from the threatened 25 per cent to 15 per cent, including for Japan‚Äôs flagship auto industry. In exchange, Japan would make concessions on opening up to US autos and agricultural products, as well as make investments in the United States worth US$550 billion. If implemented, this deal amounts to an expensive insurance against Trump‚Äôs more aggressive trade threats, trading immediate costs for medium-term stability.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has flagged the prospect of quarterly ‚Äòevaluations‚Äô of Japan‚Äôs compliance with the deal, reserving the right to have tariffs ‚Äòboomerang‚Äô to a 25 per cent rate if the ‚ÄòPresident is unhappy‚Äô.

title: High-Stakes Trade Talks: US and China Negotiations Move to Stockholm
content: Upcoming trade talks in Stockholm will see top US and Chinese officials attempt to stabilize economic tensions, with a focus on tariffs and structural reforms. The discussions aim to pave the way for ...
resumen: Upcoming trade talks in Stockholm will see top US and Chinese officials attempt to stabilize economic tensions, with a focus on tariffs and structural reforms. The discussions aim to pave the way for a potential fall meeting between President Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping, targeting balanced economic relations. In Stockholm, pivotal trade talks between US and Chinese officials might see tensions ease as the two economic superpowers negotiate current tariff levels and discuss potential structural reforms. This meeting holds the potential to lay groundwork for a forthcoming summit between President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping. The stakes are high, as both nations aim to address lingering economic issues, including significant trade deficits and China's regulatory measures on precursor chemicals for fentanyl. The US seeks to enhance its export opportunities to China, while Beijing demands easing of US tariffs, including those related to fentanyl, to resolve trade disputes. Saturday's negotiations could shape the future economic landscape, with leaders from both sides striving for comprehensive agreements that might involve shifts in US military presence in East Asia and diplomatic adjustments regarding Taiwan. As global trade tensions mount, the world watches to see if a path to resolution can indeed be achieved.

title: Hang Seng Index News: Trade Talk Hopes Lift Sentiment as 26,000 Resistance Looms
content: Hang Seng Index climbs on US-EU trade deal hopes and tech gains; focus shifts to US-China talks and Beijing‚Äôs next policy move.
resumen: The Hang Seng Index rose on trade deal hopes, but sentiment hinges on US-China talks and Beijing‚Äôs next policy moves. A US-China trade agreement with lower tariffs may push the Index above 26,000 toward the 27,000 resistance level. EV stock losses offset tech gains, dragging the Hang Seng TECH Index into negative territory despite Alibaba's rally. The Hang Seng Index advanced in early trading on Monday, July 28, reversing Friday‚Äôs losses. Investors reacted to the US and the EU reaching a trade deal, lifting hopes for a US-China trade agreement. The US and China‚Äôs third round of high-level trade talks kicks off later today. This week, trade developments, China‚Äôs private sector PMI data on July 31, and Beijing policy updates will affect market sentiment. These key drivers will determine whether the Index drops below 25,000 or rises above 26,000. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.57% to 25,534 in morning trading on July 28, eyeing the 26,000 level. Mainland China markets also trended higher. The CSI 300 and the Shanghai Composite Index posted early gains of 0.11% and 0.03%, respectively. Tech heavyweights Alibaba (9988) and JD.com (9618) led the way in Monday‚Äôs morning session, rising 2.12% and 0.84%, respectively. Electric vehicle (EV) shares offset the gains, leaving the Hang Seng TECH Index down 0.05%. EV stocks BYD (1211) and Li Auto (2015) fell 0.54% and 1.28%, respectively, dragging the Tech Index into the red. After the morning gains, the Hang Seng Index trades comfortably above its July congestion zone and the 50-day Exponential Moving Average (EMA). A US-China trade deal, including lower US tariffs on Chinese goods and easing export restrictions, could send the Hang Seng Index toward 26,000. A breakout above 26,000 could pave the way to 27,000. The risk of stalled trade talks exposes the Hang Seng to a reversal, with 25,500 the next key support level. Rising US-China trade tensions would likely weigh on risk appetite, potentially exposing the 25,000 level. Resistance: 26,000, then 27,000. Support: 25,500, followed by 25,000, and the 50-day EMA (24,118). The short-term bias remains bullish but hinges on a US-China trade deal and fresh policy from Beijing. A one-sided trade deal, including zero tariffs on US goods and US levies on Chinese shipments, could raise concerns about China sticking to any agreement. A trade deal maintaining existing US tariffs could weigh on Chinese exports and challenge Beijing‚Äôs 5% GDP growth target for 2025. Exports rose 5.8% year-on-year (YoY) in June, up from 4.8% in May. China‚Äôs economy expanded 5.2% YoY in Q2.

title: ‚ÄòAmerica needs fireworks‚Äô: No alternative for some Chinese goods amid trade uncertainty
content: The Trump administration has slapped additional 30 per cent tariffs on China since the trade war began. Read more at straitstimes.com. Read more at straitstimes.com.
resumen: Fourth of July celebrations in the US may have just passed, but Chinese businessman Marx Wu is already prepared for the dampening effect of tariffs on sales of his fireworks to American customers for the festivities in 2026. This is due to the additional 30 per cent tariffs that US President Donald Trump has been imposing on China. Mr Wu's company, Magnus Fireworks, is based in Hunan province‚Äôs Liu¬≠yang city, which is dubbed China‚Äôs ‚Äúfireworks‚Äô home town‚Äù. The US government now collects a 35.7 per cent tax from American importers of fireworks from China. 90 per cent of professional display fireworks used in the US are imported from China. US companies import close to US$400 million (S$512 million) worth of consumer fireworks from China each year. China‚Äôs exports to the US declined by 10.7 per cent in the first half of 2025 compared with the same period in 2024, a drop of US$25.7 billion. Mr Stephen Olson, a visiting senior fellow at the ISEAS ‚Äì Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore who specialises in international trade, said that despite the conflict and tension, trade between the US and China has remained remarkably resilient. Mr Steve Houser, president of Missouri-based Red Rhino Fireworks, said he has already placed his orders for 2026 but added that he ‚Äì like other major importers ‚Äì was doing so much more cautiously. The National Fireworks Association in the US was recently in Washington, DC, to make the case that fireworks should be exempt from the across-the-board tariffs of 30 per cent, as there are no viable alternative suppliers from other countries. Mr Wu Xiaoming, chief executive of Aokai Sporting Goods in Yiwu, counts the South American and African markets as his major customers ‚Äì at about 50 per cent and 20 per cent respectively ‚Äì with the US market accounting for only about 5 per cent.

title: Bloomberg Daybreak Asia: US, EU Strike Trade Agreement
content: Live market coverage co-anchored from Hong Kong and New York. Overnight on Wall Street is daytime in Asia. Markets never sleep, and neither does Bloomberg.
resumen: Stock-index futures climbed after the European Union struck a deal with President Donald Trump that will see the bloc face 15% tariffs on most exports, averting a potentially damaging trade war. S&P 500 contracts rose 0.4% and those for European stocks jumped 1%. The euro was slightly stronger against the dollar after the US-EU deal. Asian shares fluctuated at the open as Japanese equities declined 0.4%. Treasuries dipped slightly with yields on the 10-year gaining one basis point to 4.4%. Gold edged lower and oil was marginally higher. Investors are bracing for a busy week of data - including meetings of the Federal Reserve and the Bank of Japan - and earnings from megacap companies that could set the tone for the rest of the year in markets and the economy. Stocks have risen from their slump in April as investors speculate the US will strike trade deals with countries and that will help avoid significant damage to company earnings and the global economy. Australia and the UK signed a landmark 50-year defense treaty on Saturday to underpin the construction of nuclear-powered submarines, senior ministers from both nations said. Both sides stressed that the treaty doesn't impact the AUKUS security partnership between Australia, the UK and the US - currently under review by the Trump administration.
