title: EU-US trade war looms as an uneven agreement takes shape
content: With one week left before Donald Trump's deadline for a deal, with threats to impose 30% tariffs on European imports, Brussels scrambles to avert a trade war. A partial agreement is emerging, but it ...
resumen:
Con una semana antes de la fecha l√≠mite del 1 de agosto impuesta por Donald Trump, quien amenaza con imponer aranceles del 30% a las importaciones europeas si no se llega a un acuerdo entre Washington y Bruselas, Bruselas se esfuerza por evitar una guerra comercial. Se est√° gestando un acuerdo parcial, pero sigue siendo incierto dada la imprevisibilidad de Trump.

Donald Trump ha aumentado los aranceles al 25% para los autom√≥viles, al 50% para el acero y el aluminio y al 10% para una amplia gama de productos. Tambi√©n ha advertido que podr√≠a apuntar a productos farmac√©uticos o semiconductores.

La Comisi√≥n de la UE y la administraci√≥n estadounidense han estado negociando durante semanas, sin √©xito. El comisario de Comercio de la UE, Maros Sefcovic, ha viajado siete veces al otro lado del Atl√°ntico. Ha hablado con el secretario de Comercio de EE. UU., Howard Lutnick, el representante comercial de EE. UU., Jamieson Greer, y el asesor econ√≥mico de Trump, Kevin Hassett, casi todos los d√≠as.

El 23 de julio, parec√≠a posible un acuerdo, aunque estaba lejos de estar finalizado, y el impredecible presidente Trump, que tendr√≠a la √∫ltima palabra en Washington, a√∫n no hab√≠a tomado una decisi√≥n. Ese d√≠a, el jefe de gabinete de von der Leyen, Bjoern Seibert, present√≥ un esquema que podr√≠a servir de base para un acuerdo a los embajadores de los 27 estados miembros de la UE, para evaluar si los estados miembros estar√≠an dispuestos a seguirlo. Explic√≥ a los diplom√°ticos que los t√©rminos ser√≠an los siguientes: todos los bienes europeos, incluidos los productos farmac√©uticos, los semiconductores, los autom√≥viles y el acero, estar√≠an sujetos a aranceles del 15% (frente al promedio actual del 4,5%), lo que, m√°s o menos, representar√≠a la confirmaci√≥n del status quo. Se har√≠an excepciones para el sector aeroespacial y las bebidas espirituosas.

title: China‚Äôs Xi urges Europe to make ‚Äòthe right strategic choice‚Äô amid global trade turbulence at key summit
content: Chinese leader Xi Jinping urged the European Union to make ‚Äúthe right strategic choice‚Äù and enhance cooperation ...
resumen: Chinese leader Xi Jinping urged the European Union to make ‚Äúthe right strategic choice‚Äù and enhance cooperation with China. European Council President Antonio Costa and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen met with Xi on Thursday morning and Chinese Premier Li Qiang in the afternoon. The European leaders voiced concerns over a host of issues, from the trade imbalance to China‚Äôs support for Russia in the Ukraine war, and Beijing‚Äôs chokehold on the rare earths supply chain. Von der Leyen said the EU‚Äôs economic ties with China, with a trade deficit of 300 billion euros ($350 billion) last year, had reached ‚Äúan inflection point.‚Äù Costa urged Xi to use China‚Äôs influence to end Russia‚Äôs war against Ukraine. The summit, whittled from two days to a single day, is meant to celebrate 50 years of diplomatic ties between Beijing and the EU. Xi told Costa and von der Leyen that the challenges faced by Europe ‚Äúdo not come from China‚Äù and urged the EU to ‚Äúproperly handle differences and frictions.‚Äù Xi called on the bloc to keep its markets open to imports and investment while exercising ‚Äúrestraint‚Äù in using restrictive trade and other economic measures. Xi said China and the EU are ‚Äúconstructive forces that support multilateralism and advocate for openness and cooperation.‚Äù The EU raised concerns about Beijing‚Äôs ‚Äúongoing systemic distortions and growing manufacturing overcapacity.‚Äù The European leaders urged China to take concrete action to address European businesses‚Äô access to the Chinese market, end ‚Äúunjustified and retaliatory‚Äù trade measures on EU exports, and lift export controls on rare earths and permanent magnets. The EU officials vowed to take ‚Äúproportionate, legally compliant action‚Äù to protect the bloc‚Äôs interests if solutions cannot be reached. The EU repeated calls on Beijing not to provide any material support for Russia‚Äôs military-industrial base and expressed concerns over China‚Äôs policies in Xinjiang, Tibet, and Hong Kong, as well as tensions in the Taiwan Strait and the East and South China Seas. The two sides issued a joint statement on climate, pledging to ‚Äúdemonstrate leadership together‚Äù and to draw up plans to reduce planet-heating pollution before the COP30 climate conference in November. The EU has reiterated concerns over inexpensive Chinese goods ‚Äúflooding‚Äù European markets, Beijing‚Äôs move to squeeze the rare earths supply chain, and its backing for Russia. Beijing has lashed out against those concerns, including the 27-member bloc‚Äôs move last year to raise tariffs on its electric vehicles, launching its own trade probes. The EU announced it was barring Chinese companies from participating in public tenders for medical devices over a certain value, and Beijing hit back with its own curbs on government purchases of Europe-made devices. China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce slammed the EU decision to include two Chinese banks and a handful of other firms in its latest sanctions against Russia. Commerce Minister Wang Wentao lodged representations over the sanctions in a video call with EU trade chief Maros Sefcovic. Von der Leyen made clear the bloc‚Äôs deep concerns about Beijing were unresolved. Beijing has extensive control over supply chains for critical minerals key in everything from EV batteries and cell phones to fighter jets.

title: Sali√≥ el cobre: aranceles del 50%
content: Desde relatos conmovedores hasta reflexiones provocativas, estas cr√≥nicas nos invitan a explorar la complejidad y la diversidad de la vida urbana a trav√©s de los ojos y las voces de aquellos que la vi ...
resumen:
El 9 de julio, Donald Trump anunci√≥ en Truth Social un nuevo arancel del 50% al cobre, sin importar el pa√≠s de origen, con fecha de inicio el 1 de agosto de 2025.

El intercambio comercial total de cobre refinado y aleaciones de cobre en 2024 fue de 2,079 millones de d√≥lares, de los cuales 266 millones de d√≥lares corresponden a ventas internacionales y 1,814 millones de d√≥lares a compras internacionales.

En 2023, Puebla encabez√≥ las ventas internacionales por entidad federativa con el 37% de las ventas totales, seguido de Sonora con 34.5%, Nuevo Le√≥n con 17.7% y Coahuila con 6.49%.

En 2023, los pa√≠ses que m√°s compraron cobre a M√©xico fueron China con 40.6%, Estados Unidos con 30.9% y Panam√° con 16.6%.

En 2023, CDMX tuvo el mayor porcentaje de compra de cobre con el 79.4%, seguido de Baja California con 8.83%, Nuevo Le√≥n con 6.23% y el Estado de M√©xico con 4.1%.

En 2023, los pa√≠ses que m√°s vendieron cobre a M√©xico fueron Estados Unidos con 45% y Per√∫ con 28.1%.

Trump mencion√≥ que el cobre es necesario para semiconductores, aeronaves, barcos, munici√≥n, centros de datos, bater√≠as de litio, sistemas de radares, sistemas de defensa de misiles e inclusive armas hipers√≥nicas.

La Presidenta Claudia Sheinbaum mencion√≥ la intenci√≥n de buscar nuevos socios comerciales y negociar con Estados Unidos.

title: Gobierno y mineras en Chile analizan el arancel del 50% al cobre de Donald Trump
content: Codelco, Sonami, Consejo Minero, BHP, Freeport McMoran, Aprimin, Asociaci√≥n de Industriales de Antofagasta y la International Copper Association asistieron en representaci√≥n del sector privado.
resumen:
El gobierno del Presidente Gabriel Boric y representantes de las mineras en Chile analizaron este mi√©rcoles el arancel del 50% al cobre que ingrese a Estados Unidos a partir del 1 de agosto.

Del sector minero asistieron el presidente del directorio de Codelco, M√°ximo Pacheco; el presidente de la Sociedad Nacional de Miner√≠a (Sonami), Jorge Riesco; el presidente ejecutivo del Consejo Minero, Joaqu√≠n Villarino; el vicepresidente de Asuntos Corporativos Latinoam√©rica de BHP, Ren√© Muga; el country manager de Freeport McMoran, Mario Larenas; la presidenta de la Asociaci√≥n de Proveedores Industriales de la Miner√≠a (Aprimin), Dominique Viera; el gerente general de la Asociaci√≥n de Industriales de Antofagasta (AIA), Fernando Cortez; y el presidente de la International Copper Association (ICA), Juan Ignacio D√≠az (online).

Seg√∫n inform√≥ la subsecretar√≠a de Relaciones Econ√≥micas Internacionales (Subrei) en un comunicado, el evento consisti√≥ en conocer la visi√≥n de las empresas sobre el tema y el Ejecutivo inform√≥ las acciones que est√° realizando ‚Äúa la espera de conocer m√°s detalles sobre los anuncios aranceles a las importaciones de cobre al mercado estadounidense‚Äù.

Actualmente, Estados Unidos es el segundo socio comercial de Chile. Respecto a las exportaciones chilenas de cobre, EE.UU. represent√≥ el 11,1% de los env√≠os de este producto en 2024, con un total de US $5.633,8 millones, siendo casi en su totalidad c√°todos y secciones de c√°todos refinados, resalt√≥ Subrei.

Tras el encuentro y v√≠a el mismo comunicado del gobierno, el presidente de Sonami, Jorge Riesco, se√±al√≥ que ‚Äúestamos muy agradecidos de que consideren la opini√≥n del sector privado. Es importante compartir informaci√≥n, opiniones e impresiones, porque eso va generando un modelamiento mejor del escenario y puede facilitar mejores decisiones‚Äù.

En tanto, Juan Ignacio D√≠az, presidente de la International Copper Association, coment√≥ que ‚Äúdesde el inicio de la investigaci√≥n 232 en EE.UU., en la ICA hemos actuado con decisi√≥n para proteger la cadena de suministro, defender a los fabricantes estadounidenses y a nuestros productores. Hemos presentado propuestas concretas y fortalecido el trabajo con el Congreso americano. Confiamos en que, gracias a la apertura de Chile al mundo, y sin alejarnos de un aliado clave como EE.UU., saldremos adelante‚Äù.

Finalmente, la presidenta de Aprimin, Dominique Viera, se√±al√≥ que ‚Äúestamos muy contentos por la invitaci√≥n a conversar en este grupo sobre las implicancias que pueda tener un arancel sobre el cobre. Nosotros, desde el punto de vista de los proveedores, creemos que puede haber algunos riesgos. Sin embargo, en el largo plazo, al parecer todos coincidimos con que la demanda de minerales cr√≠ticos va a ser superior‚Äù.

Por parte del gobierno particip√≥ la ministra de Miner√≠a, Aurora Williams; el ministro de Econom√≠a, Nicol√°s Grau; y la subsecretaria de Relaciones Econ√≥micas Internacionales (Subrei), Claudia Sanhueza, la vicepresidenta ejecutiva (s) de Cochilco, Claudia Rodr√≠guez; y el embajador de Chile en EE.UU., Juan Gabriel Vald√©s.

title: Casa Rorty XLVIII: Guerra comercial y globalizaci√≥n en clave cosmopolita
content: Para competir en un mundo globalizado, Occidente deber√≠a olvidarse del populismo y el resentimiento y hacer reformas inteligentes.
resumen:
La negaci√≥n de la ciencia por parte de la Uni√≥n Sovi√©tica, especialmente en √°reas como la gen√©tica y la cibern√©tica, tuvo consecuencias devastadoras.

En gen√©tica, la promoci√≥n de las teor√≠as de Trofim Lysenko, que negaban la gen√©tica mendeliana, llev√≥ a la destrucci√≥n de la investigaci√≥n gen√©tica y a la implementaci√≥n de pr√°cticas agr√≠colas ineficaces, contribuyendo a la hambruna y al fracaso de la producci√≥n agr√≠cola.

En cibern√©tica, la URSS inicialmente rechaz√≥ la disciplina, consider√°ndola una "ciencia burguesa". Esto retras√≥ el desarrollo de la inform√°tica y la tecnolog√≠a de la informaci√≥n, lo que afect√≥ negativamente la capacidad de la URSS para competir tecnol√≥gicamente con Occidente.

La supresi√≥n de la investigaci√≥n cient√≠fica y la imposici√≥n de ideolog√≠as pol√≠ticas sobre la ciencia obstaculizaron el progreso cient√≠fico y tecnol√≥gico en la URSS, con graves consecuencias econ√≥micas y sociales.

title: War between India, Pak would have ended nuclear: Trump
content: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday claimed yet again that he stopped the recent "war" between India and Pakistan and that five planes were shot down in the conflict.
resumen: On July 24, 2025, US President Donald Trump claimed he stopped the recent ‚Äúwar‚Äù between India and Pakistan and that five planes were shot down in the conflict. title: Logistics rents extend slump in China as suppliers relocate to hedge against tariff war
content: Logistics property owners are losing out to their rivals in India, where rents increased this year from the second half of 2024.
resumen: Rents on logistics properties in mainland China extended a slump into the first half of this year. Rents declined 12.8 per cent in the first six months from a year earlier, according to Knight Frank. The market weakened by 14.1 per cent in the July to December period last year. Beijing and Shanghai highlighted the shrinking demand as rents tumbled 17.2 per cent and 11.3 per cent, respectively, this year. The vacancy rate climbed to 28.9 per cent in Beijing and 26.8 per cent in Shanghai. The prospect of rents bottoming out is unlikely within the next 12 months, according to Christine Li, Asia-Pacific head of research at Knight Frank. India reported the strongest logistics rental growth in the Asia-Pacific region. Rents climbed 3.4 per cent, versus 2.1 per cent in the second half of 2024.

title: US automakers say Trump's 15% tariff deal with Japan puts them at a disadvantage
content: U.S. automakers worry that President Donald Trump‚Äôs agreement to tariff Japanese vehicles at 15% would put them at a competitive disadvantage, saying they will face steeper import taxes on steel, ...
resumen:
U.S. automakers worry that President Donald Trump‚Äôs agreement to tariff Japanese vehicles at 15% would put them at a competitive disadvantage, saying they will face steeper import taxes on steel, aluminum and parts than their competitors.

Matt Blunt, president of the American Automotive Policy Council, which represents the Big 3 American automakers, General Motors, Ford and Jeep-maker Stellantis, said the U.S. companies and workers ‚Äúdefinitely are at a disadvantage‚Äù because they face a 50% tariff on steel and aluminum and a 25% tariff on parts and finished vehicles, with some exceptions for products covered under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement that went into effect in 2020.

The United Auto Workers said in a statement it was ‚Äúdeeply angered‚Äù by the deal.

Trump portrayed the trade framework as a major win after announcing it on Tuesday, saying it would add hundreds of thousands of jobs to the U.S. economy and open the Japanese economy in ways that could close a persistent trade imbalance.

The agreement includes a 15% tariff that replaces the 25% import tax the Republican president had threatened to charge starting on Aug. 1.

Japan would also put together $550 billion to invest in U.S. projects at the ‚Äúdirection‚Äù of the president, the White House said.

The framework with Japan will remove regulations that prevent American vehicles from being sold in that country, the White House has said.

Karl Brauer, executive analyst at iSeeCars, said the agreement provides Japan with a near-term operating cost advantage compared to other foreign automakers, and even some domestic U.S. product that uses a high degree of both foreign production and parts content.

Autos Drive America, an organization that represents major Japanese companies Toyota, Honda and Nissan and other international automakers, said in a statement that it is ‚Äúencouraged‚Äù by the announced trade framework and noted its members have exceeded domestic automaker production for the past two years.

The statement urged "the Trump administration to swiftly reach similar agreements with other allies and partners, especially the European Union, South Korea, Canada and Mexico.‚Äù

Sam Fiorani, vice president at consultancy AutoForecast Solutions, said Ford, GM and Stellantis do ‚Äúhave every right to be upset.‚Äù

content: Empresas que fabrican de todo, desde chips hasta acero, reportaron resultados con tendencias a la baja este mi√©rcoles, con la guerra comercial del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, ...
resumen:
Empresas que fabrican de todo, desde chips hasta acero, reportaron resultados con tendencias a la baja este mi√©rcoles, con la guerra comercial del presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, infligiendo da√±os incluso pese a que su pacto con Jap√≥n impuls√≥ las acciones y las esperanzas de que Europa haga lo mismo.

Las bolsas asi√°ticas y europeas subieron, ya que los inversionistas aplaudieron el acuerdo comercial entre Estados Unidos y Jap√≥n, que rebaja los aranceles a las importaciones de autos y evita a Tokio nuevos grav√°menes sobre otros bienes.

Los resultados de Texas Instruments y del fabricante de acero SSAB mostraron c√≥mo la ca√≥tica pol√≠tica comercial estadounidense ya ha perjudicado a los beneficios, aumentando los costos, trastornando las cadenas de suministro y lastrando la confianza de los consumidores.

El informe trimestral de resultados de Texas Instruments apunt√≥ a una demanda de sus chips anal√≥gicos menor de lo esperado por parte de algunos clientes y subray√≥ la incertidumbre arancelaria.

Fabricantes de semiconductores como Texas Instruments a√∫n no se enfrentan directamente a los elevados aranceles de Trump, pero el costo de las herramientas de fabricaci√≥n ha aumentado y algunos de sus clientes finales han recortado el gasto.

El fabricante holand√©s de equipos para chips inform√°ticos ASM International advirti√≥ de que la entrada de pedidos de los fabricantes fue ‚Äúirregular‚Äù en el segundo trimestre.

Neil Wilson, estratega de inversiones de Saxo Markets, afirm√≥ que ‚Äúlos aranceles est√°n golpeando fuerte‚Äù.

Las empresas informaron de una p√©rdida combinada para todo el a√±o de entre 6 mil 600 y 7 mil 800 millones de d√≥lares entre el 16 y el 22 de julio, siendo los sectores automovil√≠stico, aeroespacial y farmac√©utico los m√°s perjudicados.

General Motors reiter√≥ el martes su expectativa de un golpe de entre 4 mil y 5 mil millones de d√≥lares por los aranceles para 2025.

La finlandesa Nokia acus√≥ a los vientos en contra de los aranceles y a la debilidad del d√≥lar al rebajar sus previsiones para 2025.

Para la sider√∫rgica sueca SSAB, el mayor problema es que los aranceles est√°n provocando que m√°s env√≠os de acero barato se redirijan a Europa.

Johnny Sjostrom, presidente ejecutivo de SSAB, dijo que ‚ÄúLas turbulencias de los aranceles y las barreras comerciales provocaron un aumento de la incertidumbre‚Äù, con el mayor impacto visto en el debilitamiento del mercado europeo del acero.

Aunque el acuerdo con Jap√≥n alivi√≥ las preocupaciones de los inversores, persiste la amenaza de aranceles m√°s altos en otras grandes econom√≠as, como la Uni√≥n Europea, Canad√° y Brasil.

Trump tambi√©n ha amenazado con grav√°menes sectoriales m√°s elevados sobre los productos farmac√©uticos, los chips y el cobre.

Los analistas de Deutsche Bank dijeron que esto est√° lejos del final.

El secretario de Asuntos Econ√≥micos del Ministerio de Asuntos Exteriores brasile√±o, Philip Gough, advirti√≥ que pol√≠ticas como la impulsada por la administraci√≥n de Trump pueden empujar la econom√≠a global hacia una ‚Äúespiral de precios altos y estancamiento‚Äù. Critic√≥ el uso de tasas como instrumento para influir en los asuntos internos de otros pa√≠ses, se√±al√°ndola como una estrategia ‚Äúextremadamente peligrosa‚Äù que atenta contra el equilibrio del sistema multilateral. Brasil mantiene su compromiso con el di√°logo para la resoluci√≥n de disputas comerciales, pero que, si esa instancia resulta inviable, el pa√≠s est√° preparado para utilizar todos los mecanismos legales disponibles, incluida la mediaci√≥n de la OMC. Brasil denunci√≥ un preocupante giro en el uso de aranceles como herramienta de presi√≥n pol√≠tica. Seg√∫n Gough, m√°s all√° de las violaciones sistem√°ticas a las reglas del comercio internacional, ‚Äúlo m√°s preocupante es el intento de emplear medidas arancelarias para interferir en los asuntos internos de pa√≠ses soberanos‚Äù. Brasil ha insistido en que es esencial que la OMC recupere su papel como un lugar "donde todos los pa√≠ses pueden resolver disputas y hacer valer intereses leg√≠timos a trav√©s del di√°logo y la negociaci√≥n". 40 pa√≠ses (27 de ellos pertenecientes a la Uni√≥n Europea) manifestaron su apoyo a la defensa del multilateralismo y la urgencia de reformar organismos como la OMC. Entre ellos figuran China, India, Canad√° y Colombia. El presidente estadounidense indic√≥ que estar√≠a dispuesto a revisar las medidas arancelarias si sus socios comerciales eliminan las ‚Äúbarreras‚Äù que afectan sus exportaciones. De lo contrario, advirti√≥ que los grav√°menes podr√≠an aumentar. Las sanciones anunciadas por Trump contra Brasil est√°n basadas en argumentos que van desde ‚Äúla forma en que Brasil trat√≥ al expresidente Bolsonaro...‚Äù y ‚Äúlos ataques insidiosos de Brasil a las elecciones libres y los derechos fundamentales de libertad de expresi√≥n...‚Äù hasta la ‚Äúmuy injusta relaci√≥n comercial de larga data‚Äù que sostienen con Estados Unidos. Brasil reporta una relaci√≥n comercial superavitaria de 450 mil millones de d√≥lares con Estados Unidos, y es uno de los pa√≠ses con mayor presencia de filiales de empresas de esa naci√≥n. title: U.S. tariffs are hurting all auto workers. Canada isn't the enemy. | Opinion
content: Our automotive industries are deeply connected; our workers share the same struggles. Yet today, that relationship is under threat from a wave of U.S. tariffs that are hurting Canadian workers. Indeed ...
resumen: Canada and the U.S. have built cars and prosperity together for half a century. Auto unions on both sides of the border have fought for better working conditions and fair-trade agreements. The automotive industries are deeply connected, and the workers share the same struggles. This relationship is under threat from U.S. tariffs that are hurting Canadian and American workers. Free trade agreements, along with other failed economic policies, have contributed to major job losses in both countries. In the last decade, Canada has seen its share of North American vehicle production fall from 13% to 9%. The U.S. has also seen a decline from 68% to 66%. Canada buys about two million vehicles per year but built far less than that in 2024. Last year, 5 million vehicles were sold in North America that weren‚Äôt made on this continent. Current U.S. trade policy is increasingly targeting its closest ally, causing layoffs, and creating uncertainty for workers on both sides of the border. The U.S. and Canada share an exceptional trading relationship in the auto sector. Canada sells $72 billion CAD in vehicles and parts to the U.S. and buys $77 billion back. Canada has been hit with multiple rounds of tariffs: 25% on non-U.S. content in vehicles, another 25% tied to fentanyl and border compliance rules and an initial 25% on steel and aluminum, now rising to 50%. Amid tariff threats, Stellantis paused the retooling of Brampton Assembly Plant in Ontario. Stellantis idled Windsor Assembly Plant. Workers were laid off, at least temporarily, on both sides of the border. Canada has been building cars since 1904. The U.S.-Canada Auto Pact of the 1960s created the most integrated auto industries in the world. The U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) needs to do better for workers. A new trade deal should incentivize local production and raise labor standards across North America. Stronger continental trade should drive global automakers to bolster North America as a world leader in vehicle innovation. Lana Payne is the national president of Unifor, Canada's largest private sector union. She is also a member of the Prime Minister‚Äôs Council on Canada-U.S. Relations.

title: Will Courts Strip the White House of Its Trade War Weapon?
content: The panel, which handed down a unanimous decision against Trump, was an eclectic one, with judges appointed by Presidents Ronald Reagan, Barack Obama, and Trump himself. The panel vacated the IEEPA ...
resumen: Two federal appeals courts are sending signals regarding President Trump‚Äôs IEEPA tariffs. Two federal courts have ruled that President Trump‚Äôs IEEPA tariffs are unlawful and unconstitutional. Trump has appealed these rulings. One of the rulings against Trump was a 3-0 decision on May 28 by the Court of International Trade (CIT). The panel vacated the IEEPA tariffs that Trump had ordered to date, and issued a permanent injunction against such tariffs in the future. The Federal Circuit Court of Appeals stayed the CIT ruling while it hears an appeal. Oral arguments on the appeal are scheduled for July 31. The court is expected to hear oral arguments en banc, which means that all 11 active judges in the court will participate. Eight of the judges on the Federal Circuit were appointed by Democratic presidents, three were appointed by Republicans, and none were appointed by Trump. The D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals has selected a three judge panel consisting entirely of Trump appointments to hear Trump‚Äôs appeal of a May 29 decision from the District of Columbia District Court. This ruling, like the CIT decision, found the IEEPA tariffs to be unlawful and unconstitutional. There are 11 active judges on the D.C. Circuit Court of Appeals. Only three of them were appointed by Trump. Oral arguments in the D.C. Circuit are set for September 30. IEEPA tariffs will be accumulating at about $25 billion per month starting August 1.

title: Trump Tariffs Would Hit Hungary Hard Despite Warm Relations With MAGA-Friendly Orb√°n
content: Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orb√°n has built a close relationship with Donald Trump, aligning with the MAGA movement ...
resumen: Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orb√°n has built a close relationship with Donald Trump, aligning with the MAGA movement. Trump announced he would levy tariffs of 30% against Mexico and the EU beginning Aug. 1. Hungary is poised to be among those hard hit by Trump‚Äôs tariffs against the European Union. Hungary is a small, export-oriented economy with major automobile, pharmaceutical and wine industries. Outgoing trade to the United States represents around 15% of all Hungarian exports to countries outside the EU. P√©ter Virov√°cz, chief analyst at ING Hungary, said the duties ‚Äúwould put the Hungarian economy in a very, very difficult situation, because then the entire possibility for Hungary to export to America would be essentially eliminated.‚Äù G√°bor B√°nfalvi, co-owner of Taste Hungary, said his company will likely cease doing business in the U.S. altogether if the 30% duty is levied on its products. Taste Hungary has been shipping around 10,000 bottles of premium Hungarian wine per year to the U.S. for about half a decade. The value of EU-U.S. trade in goods and services in 2024 amounted to 1.7 trillion euros ($2 trillion.). Hungary‚Äôs government has acknowledged that the tariffs would present a challenge. Orb√°n said in an interview in April that while tariffs ‚Äúwill be a disadvantage,‚Äù his government was negotiating ‚Äúother economic agreements and issues that will offset them.‚Äù P√©ter Krek√≥, director of the Budapest-based Political Capital think tank, expressed doubt that political affinities could play a meaningful role in mitigating damage to Hungary‚Äôs economy caused by Trump‚Äôs trade policy. Hungary is home to numerous automobile factories for major automakers like Audi and Mercedes. Pharmaceuticals make up an even larger share of Hungarian exports to the United States ‚Äî an industry on which Trump this month threatened to impose 200% tariffs. Virov√°cz said that it‚Äôs impossible for tariffs to be levied on EU products but not on Hungarian ones. Krek√≥ said Trump‚Äôs administration ‚Äúgives practically nothing for free. If Hungary ... cannot fulfill the interests of the U.S., then I think Hungary is not going to receive gifts.‚Äù

title: The EU shouldn't fight Trump's tariffs alone, former WTO chief warns
content: The European Union should form an alliance with the United States' other trading partners to counter the president's 'hostage-taking' tactics, ...
resumen: The European Union should form an alliance with the United States' other trading partners to counter President Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúhostage-taking‚Äù tactics, according to Pascal Lamy, former Director-General of the World Trade Organization (WTO) from 2005 to 2013 and former European Commissioner for trade. Lamy told The Parliament in an interview that the EU should join forces with other countries targeted by US tariffs to retaliate against President Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúhostage-taking‚Äù tactics. Such a coalition could be comprised of the EU, China, Indonesia, India, South Africa, Japan, South Korea and other countries. Lamy‚Äôs plea to stage a coordinated response to the US with other WTO members comes after Trump‚Äôs threat earlier this month to impose a crippling 30% baseline tariff on EU goods. The EU ‚Äî America's largest trading partner ‚Äî is already grappling with a 10% baseline rate on all exports to the US, along with a 50% levy on European steel and aluminium, and a 25% tax on car sales. As of late Wednesday, the EU and US were reportedly nearing a deal that would set a 15% baseline tariff on European exports, in the same vein as the agreement Trump reached with Japan earlier in the week. Less than three months after returning to office, Trump unleashed sweeping tariffs on over 180 trading partners, including the European Union, contending they would help balance out a $773.4 billion US trade deficit. The EU has finalised a first set of countermeasures to retaliate against the steel and aluminium tariffs, which would target roughly ‚Ç¨21 billion in US exports to the bloc ‚Äî but has repeatedly decided not to pull the trigger in a bid to avert a painful escalation of the trade conflict. European diplomats have also drafted a second set of retaliatory measures ‚Äî taking aim at an additional ‚Ç¨72 billion worth of US goods ‚Äî and are now reportedly considering utilising the bloc‚Äôs powerful Anti-Coercion Instrument if a trade deal falls apart. For Lamy, only a broad international coalition would generate enough firepower to strike the US where it hurts most. The EU has not been particularly active in pursuing this path. European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced last month that Brussels was considering joining the Asian-led Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP). Lamy dismissed the idea. If Trump were to move forward with a 30% tariff rate, the choice is clear for Lamy: retaliation.

title: Beijing‚Äôs Trade Tactics, Ukraine Stance Cast Pall Over Europe-China Ties
content: After Trump‚Äôs election, China and Europe sought warmer ties, but rifts over Russia and trade sparked conflict.
resumen: China and Europe face a common threat from President Trump‚Äôs tariffs, but that isn‚Äôt enough to bring the two economies closer. European frustration is mounting over Beijing‚Äôs support for Russia‚Äôs war in Ukraine and what officials view as a flood of low-cost products on global markets. These concerns loom over a summit between European Union and Chinese leaders in Beijing on Thursday, which was billed as a chance to mark 50 years of diplomatic relations between the two economies, but officials on both sides are striking a somber tone amid growing pessimism about the relationship. The summit has already been shrunk to a single day from two‚Äîat China‚Äôs behest. Europeans say they want China to take concrete steps to address their concerns. China wants to enlist the EU‚Äôs help in pushing back against Trump‚Äôs trade policies, and Beijing views the bloc‚Äôs criticisms of its industrial and trade policies as misguided. Chinese leader Xi Jinping told visiting EU leaders in Beijing on Thursday that Chinese and European leaders must ‚Äúmake the right strategic choices‚Äù amid a fast-changing and tumultuous global environment. The EU has toughened its stance toward Beijing in recent years. The European Commission refers to China as a rival, and its president, Ursula von der Leyen, says she wants to curb Europe‚Äôs reliance on China for vital materials. Germany pledged earlier this year to reduce risks in its economic relationship with China. At a meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized economies last month, von der Leyen accused China of creating a pattern of ‚Äúdominance, dependency and blackmail‚Äù and called for a united response. Von der Leyen is attending the summit along with European Council President Ant√≥nio Costa. The two leaders met Xi on Thursday and are due to meet with Chinese Premier Li Qiang later in the day. China has sought to position itself as a force for stability and an antidote to Trump‚Äôs trade measures, offering olive branches that have included lifting sanctions against European lawmakers and easing visa requirements. Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi recently dismissed concerns that China‚Äôs export controls on rare earth elements are fueling discord with Europe, saying that as long as Chinese regulations are adhered to, ‚Äúthe normal demands of European companies will be guaranteed.‚Äù European officials remain unconvinced, and question whether Beijing will address their basic economic concerns. Some think China could expand activities that would hurt European companies. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesman Guo Jiakun said at a briefing on Monday that ‚Äúthe China-EU relationship does face some challenges‚Äù and that ‚Äúsome in the EU‚Äù have ‚Äúexaggerated specific economic and trade issues and groundlessly accused China on the Ukraine issue.‚Äù The summit comes on the heels of a World Trade Organization arbitration ruling on Monday that gave the EU a partial win in an intellectual-property dispute with China centered on mobile technology. A European Parliament delegation visited Taipei this week, meeting Taiwan President Lai Ching-te and other officials‚Äîa form of engagement that China has long denounced as a challenge to its sovereignty claims over the self-governed island. The EU has launched several investigations into Chinese subsidies. Last month, it announced plans to exclude Chinese companies from bidding on public procurement above 5 million euros, equivalent to about $5.9 million, for medical devices. The bloc also blacklisted half a dozen Chinese firms in its latest sanctions package targeting Russia, including for the first time two regional Chinese banks. Beijing played down tensions with the EU ahead of the summit and urged the bloc to seek common ground with China. During a visit earlier this month to Brussels, Berlin and Paris, Wang, the Chinese foreign minister, urged European leaders to take a positive and pragmatic approach toward China. Wang also told EU foreign-policy chief Kaja Kallas that Beijing didn‚Äôt want to see Russia lose the war because it would mean the U.S. turning its attention fully toward China. EU leaders traveled to China after a summit in Japan on Wednesday. The bloc is looking to deepen ties with Tokyo on defense, trade and economic security and believes the two sides share similar concerns over China‚Äôs economic policies and its support for Russia. Washington and Brussels appear to be nearing a deal that would set tariffs on European exports to the U.S. at 15%. EU and Chinese officials are in talks about a possible price agreement on electric vehicles that could replace the bloc‚Äôs tariffs. The European and Chinese leaders will also discuss climate issues. The EU is going to the summit with the expectation ‚Äúthat the Chinese will first understand our concerns, and second take concrete actions as soon as possible,‚Äù a senior EU official said last week.

title: Europe and Brazil do not lower their heads in the tariff war
content: The new commercial barriers imposed by the US reveal not only extreme protectionism, but an authoritarian and undemocratic stance that despises agreements, alliances and the right of each nation ...
resumen: The new commercial barriers imposed by the US reveal extreme protectionism, an authoritarian and undemocratic stance that despises agreements, alliances, and the right of each nation to lead their own ways. Europe and Brazil are pushed to the corners by Donald Trump‚Äôs fierce protectionism. The crusade of tariffs imposed by the president of the United States is a direct attack on national sovereignty, multilateralism, and the foundations that support global trade since the postwar. The new round of tariffs announced by Trump reaches historical partners from the United States. Europe and Brazil together see billionaire rates are announced as those who throw missiles into a war that no one has declared. In the European case, the package is heavy: 25% on cars, 50% over copper and other tariffs aiming at strategic sectors such as medicines, semiconductors and industrial equipment. For Brazil, retaliation came with the same intensity. From August 1, Brazilian products will suffer a 50% surcharge ‚Äì a unilateral decision that ignores any attempt at dialogue or cooperation. This climbing is not economical; it is ideological. It is the reflection of a nationalist foreign policy based on threats, blackmail, and impositions. Trump does not act as a head of state, but as a commercial caudillo, driven by electoral impulses and the belief that the world should revolve around the United States. Its decisions harm allies, weaken global stability and corrode the pillars of international diplomacy. The climate in Brussels is urgent. The European Union prepares retaliation that total almost ‚Ç¨ 100 billion, aiming at symbolic sectors of the US economy: Boeing, Bourbon, Motorcycles, Soy. In Brazil, President Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva said in an exclusive interview with CNN International: ‚ÄúThe relationship between the two countries cannot continue like this.‚Äù He said he is willing to dialogue but requires respect for Brazilian sovereignty ‚Äì and his people, institutions and decisions. Brazil is the second largest supplier to the US market ‚Äì behind only China ‚Äì and now sees its oil exports, among others, are arbitrarily penalized. Trump tries to redesign international relations based on brute force and imbalance. Tariffs are only the visible tip of an authoritarian iceberg. Behind them is a world project in which the United States is allowed to impose rules, manipulate markets, blackmail partners, and reduce multilateral treaties to pieces of paper. Europe prepares the use of the anticking instrument (ACI), a powerful tool created precisely to react to external pressures such as Trump‚Äôs. This mechanism would allow the imposition of severe sanctions against US companies and strategic sectors if threats are materialized. Brazilian diplomacy cannot remain hostage to contradictory nods or the hope that Trump to retreat on its own. It‚Äôs time to reposition the country in the world. The EU deficit has grown not because of Europe, but by anticipations of imports by US companies. To tax Brazil by 50% is to punish a partner for complying with the rules of the game. Trump isolates the United States in an increasingly interconnected world. The moment requires political courage. It requires leaders like Lula, Macron, Scholz, S√°nchez and so many others say, with all the letters, that the sovereignty of the peoples is not for sale. Trump‚Äôs crusade against free trade is also a crusade against democracy. Resistance begins to gain body. In Brasilia, Lula‚Äôs reaction is a step. In Brussels, the contracted are already designed. It is necessary to build a global alliance that defends not only fair rates, but the principles of sovereignty, dialogue, and international justice.

title: Gobierno de EU sol√≠a ser un socio estable para organizaciones sin fines de lucro. Eso ha cambiado
content: En los primeros d√≠as de su segundo mandato, Trump congel√≥ o amenaz√≥ con recortar una amplia gama de programas de servicios sociales, desde seguridad p√∫blica hasta servicios para el reasentamiento de r ...
resumen:
El gobierno de EU sol√≠a ser un socio estable para organizaciones sin fines de lucro, pero eso ha cambiado. En los primeros d√≠as de su segundo mandato, Donald Trump congel√≥, recort√≥ o amenaz√≥ con recortar una amplia gama de programas de servicios sociales, desde seguridad p√∫blica hasta servicios para el reasentamiento de refugiados.

Dawn Price, directora ejecutiva de Friendship Shelter, relata que en febrero, el acceso a una cuenta financiada por una subvenci√≥n de la agencia federal de vivienda fue suspendido temporalmente, como parte de los recortes y la congelaci√≥n de fondos del gobierno de Trump.

En respuesta a preguntas sobre los recortes a las subvenciones, Kush Desai, portavoz de la Casa Blanca, afirm√≥ que el gobierno de Trump se enfoca en impulsar el resurgimiento econ√≥mico de Estados Unidos para impulsar la generosidad individual de los estadounidenses.

En 2021, se otorgaron 267,000 millones de d√≥lares a organizaciones sin fines de lucro por parte de todos los niveles de gobierno, seg√∫n un an√°lisis publicado en febrero por el Urban Institute.

El an√°lisis del Urban Institute muestra que m√°s de la mitad de las organizaciones sin fines de lucro en cada estado recibieron subvenciones gubernamentales en 2021.

Taryn Palumbo, directora ejecutiva de Orange County Grantmakers, indic√≥ que las organizaciones sin fines de lucro est√°n viendo que sus presupuestos se recortan entre un 50% o un 40%.

La Fundaci√É¬≥n Samueli local encarg√≥ un estudio sobre las necesidades de las organizaciones sin fines de lucro, y encontraron que las organizaciones sin fines de lucro locales reportaron problemas para mantener a su personal, una profunda falta de inversi√≥n en sus operaciones y una escasez de fondos de reserva flexibles. Lindsey Spindle, presidenta de la fundaci√≥n, inform√≥ que recibieron 1,242 solicitudes por m√°s de 250 millones de d√≥lares, frente a los 10 millones de d√≥lares potencialmente disponibles.

Desde la d√©cada de 1960, el gobierno federal ha financiado en gran medida estos servicios sociales mediante donaciones a organizaciones sin fines de lucro, universidades, hospitales y empresas.

Claire Dunning, profesora adjunta de pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas en la Universidad de Maryland, College Park, explic√≥ que el gobierno federal ha continuado su financiaci√≥n a las organizaciones sin fines de lucro a niveles significativos.

En enero, el gobierno de Trump intent√≥ congelar las subvenciones y pr√©stamos federales.

El Friendship Shelter, en Laguna Beach, tiene un presupuesto anual de aproximadamente 15 millones de d√≥lares, de los cuales 11,5 millones provienen de fuentes gubernamentales.

Price report√≥ que la financiaci√≥n gubernamental est√° "entrelazada" de maneras complejas para albergar y apoyar a 330 personas. Ya perdieron una subvenci√≥n de reembolso de alquiler del Departamento de Vivienda y Desarrollo Urbano (HUD, por sus siglas en ingl√©s) de Estados Unidos. La Fundaci√É¬≥n Samueli intervino para compensar esos fondos perdidos durante tres a√É¬±os.

Lindsey Spindle cree que incluso en un lugar adinerado como el Condado de Orange, no se puede esperar que los donantes aumenten su apoyo cinco, seis u ocho veces m√°s de lo que donan actualmente.

title: Australia lifts US beef ban after Trump tariffs threat
content: Australia said today it would lift trade barriers on beef from the United States, removing a major point of friction between Canberra and the ...
resumen:
Australia will lift trade barriers on beef from the United States.
US President Donald Trump singled out Australia as he unveiled his ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù tariffs in April, accusing the close ally of banning American meat while cashing in on exports to the United States.
Australia‚Äôs stringent biosecurity rules block imports of cattle slaughtered in the United States, but born in Canada or Mexico.
Threatened with 10 per cent tariffs on beef shipped to the United States, Australia has now dropped these barriers.
Agriculture minister Julie Collins said the United States had adopted new quality controls that soothed Australia‚Äôs worries.
Australia suspended US beef imports in 2003 after an outbreak of mad cow disease.
Most of these restrictions were lifted in 2019, although some barriers remained on cattle slaughtered in American abattoirs but born elsewhere.
Trump said Australians were ‚Äúwonderful people‚Äù but accused them of banning US beef while exporting billions of dollars worth of meat to America.
US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick had also namechecked Australia.
Almost five per cent of all the beef eaten in America is Australian.
In the first three weeks of July, Australia shipped almost 25,000 tonnes of beef and veal to the United States.
Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has been unusually frank in his condemnation of Trump‚Äôs trade war.

title: Trump treating tariffs like ‚Äòreality TV show,‚Äô Sen. Patty Murray says
content: Sen. Patty Murray responds to Trump's 35% tariff plan on Canadian goods, highlighting its impact on trade and the economy.
resumen:
U.S. President Donald Trump calls on a reporter during a meeting with Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. in the Oval Office at the White House on July 22, 2025 in Washington, DC.
With President Donald Trump promising to impose a 35% tariff on Canadian goods starting August 1, U.S. Senator Patty Murray of Washington and British Columbia Premier David Eby are sounding the alarm.
The U.S. has already imposed a 50% tariff on steel and aluminum, which Canada exports to the U.S.
Eby asserted at a virtual news conference Wednesday, ‚Äúis a recipe for mutually assured destruction.‚Äù
Eby noted that the Trump administration has threatened or imposed tariffs on countries worldwide, referencing the 1930 Smoot-Hawley Tariff Act.
Murray pointed out that the growing trade dispute with Canada puts Washington in a particularly vulnerable position.
Murray said, ‚ÄúWe actually import nearly $18 billion in goods from Canada each year,‚Äù pointing out the benefits go both ways. ‚ÄúCanada is one of our largest trading partners, accounting for, every year, nearly $8 billion in exports, including our seafood, apples, and airplane parts, and more than $2 billion in cross-border tourism and business.‚Äù
Eby said the trade war, and Trump‚Äôs suggestion that Canada become the 51st U.S. state, are already taking a toll on tourism from Canada.
‚ÄúCross-border visits from B.C. to Washington are down 35%,‚Äù he said.
Eby added that Canadians are boycotting some U.S. goods, including alcohol.
A Canadian liquor trade group said sales of U.S. spirits dropped 66.3% between March 5 and April, according to Reuters.
Murray doesn‚Äôt blame Canada, but rather Trump‚Äôs tariff policies, and she supports legislation that would reassert congress‚Äô authority over tariffs and trade policies.
Murray claimed, ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very clear that Trump wants to treat tariffs like some reality TV show, constantly playing up the outrage and the uncertainty of the ‚Äòwill he won‚Äôt he‚Äô drama that he seems to like living in.‚Äù
Trump insists there has long been a trade imbalance between the U.S. and countries around the world, including its neighbor Canada.
He said tariffs will bring manufacturing back to the U.S. and force our border countries, Canada and Mexico, to work harder to keep illegal drugs and undocumented immigrants from slipping into the U.S.

title: Trump‚Äôs Japan deal is a hollow victory
content: The reaction of markets to the US trade deal with Japan shows yet again that if you presage bad news with even worse news you can make people pathetically grateful at the outcome.
resumen:
The US trade deal with Japan will see imports of Japanese cars to the US slapped with tariffs of 15 percent.
Donald Trump announced that Japanese imports would be subject to 24 percent tariffs on ‚ÄúLiberation Day‚Äù in April.
The deal with Japan shows that Trump hasn‚Äôt really chickened out at all.
The outcome is balanced: imports of Japanese cars to the US will now attract the same tariff ‚Äì 15 percent ‚Äì as imports of American cars to Japan.
The Japanese will also remove quotas.
In the case of countries which are prepared to negotiate, we will end up with US import tariffs which are markedly lower than those announced on Liberation Day but which are nevertheless higher than those that existed before 2 April.
The World Trade Organization gave an average tariff rate for the US of 3.4 percent, for Japan it was 4.2 percent, the EU 5.2 percent, the UK 3.9 percent and China 7.5 percent.
Bottom of the WTO‚Äôs list for import tariffs is Singapore.

title: Donald Trump's broken promise: American consumers are beginning to pay the price for tariffs
content: Trump vowed to cut costs, but his tariffs are fueling inflation instead. Imported goods are pricier, wage gains are being wiped out, and Americans are starting to feel the financial pinch.
resumen:
Donald Trump promised American voters that he would reduce the cost of living and end the ¬´nightmare of inflation.¬ª

Data released this week shows that prices in the U.S. are picking up again. Annual inflation rose more sharply than expected in June, climbing from 2.4% to 2.7%. Stripping out volatile categories such as food and energy, so-called core inflation rose to 2.9%.

Inflation has been moving away from the 2% target for months. Trump and his tariff policy are to blame.

Tiffany Wilding, economist at asset manager Pimco, says that companies are increasingly passing on the higher customs costs to consumers.

Wilding expects core inflation to rise to 3.4% by the end of the year.

The Yale Budget Lab research group has calculated that the average effective tariff rate has risen from 2.5% in January to 20.6%. The research group estimates that this will result in a loss of income of $2,800 per U.S. household by 2025.

Goldman Sachs Research estimates that companies are likely to pass on around 70% of direct tariff costs to consumers in the form of higher prices.

While average hourly earnings rose by 0.2%, consumer prices climbed by 0.3%.

Trump posted on his Truth Social platform: ¬´ Consumer Prices LOW. Bring down the Fed Rate, NOW!!!¬ª He doubled down: ¬´The USA is Rockin', there is VERY LOW INFLATION,¬ª arguing that key interest rates should be at 1%. He claims this would save the U.S. $1 trillion dollars a year in interest costs.

title: Can the euro replace the dollar? Trump‚Äôs tariffs shake confidence in US currency as euro surges
content: As the dollar falls and foreign investors rush into the euro, Europe has fresh threats and opportunities in the new financial order.
resumen: The US dollar is losing value in 2025, prompting investors and central banks to look for safer bets. The euro has climbed more than 11 percent against the dollar since the start of the year to $1.18, its highest point in four years. The euro has also gained strength against other major currencies like the Japanese yen, British pound, and Canadian dollar. European Central Bank chief Christine Lagarde labeled this as a "profound shift" in world order. The dollar's predominance has long given the US the ability to borrow cheaply and easily. Trump's volatile economic policies are eroding that foundation. Export-driven economies like Germany are grumbling that a high euro, combined with US tariffs, is undermining their competitiveness. SAP said that each one-cent appreciation of the euro-dollar rate shaves ‚Ç¨30 million off its revenues. A stronger euro also threatens to drag down inflation. The ECB predicts 1.6 percent inflation next year. Future cuts in interest rates are now being discussed by ECB officials after cutting eight times in the last twelve months. Some analysts see a chance for Europe to lead the effort to create a truly "global euro." Lagarde cautioned that global stature will not be automatic. It would take structural reforms. The rise of the euro in 2025 is a turning point in global finance.

title: ECB holds rates as Trump tariff talks go to the wire
content: US president Donald Trump has threatened to triple a basic tariff on imports from the EU to 30 per cent if Brussels does not cut a deal by August 1st ...
resumen: The European Central Bank (ECB) left interest rates unchanged on Thursday. The ECB kept its key deposit rate at 2 per cent. Economists generally expect the governing council to reduce official rates by a quarter of a percentage point in September. US president Donald Trump has threatened to triple a basic tariff on imports from the EU to 30 per cent if Brussels does not cut a deal by August 1st. Negotiators from the EU are currently said to be edging towards accepting US import tariffs of 15 per cent as the price of an accord. The ECB cut its deposit rate from 4 per cent to 2 per cent between June 2024 and last month. Euro zone inflation has fallen back to the ECB‚Äôs 2 per cent target, as of June, from a peak of 10.6 per cent seen in late 2022. Officials at the central bank expect consumer price growth to even out at 2 per cent for the whole year, too.

title: Europe‚Äôs central bank to hold off on another rate cut until it knows how bad the tariff blow will be
content: The European Central Bank probably isn't going to cut interest rates again on Thursday. That's because the bank's leaders don't know what kind of headwinds they'll be facing from U.S. trade policy.

title: Gobierno. Silencio de Milei ante pol√©micos dichos del nuevo embajador de EE.UU. sobre la relaci√≥n de Argentina y China
content: El diplom√°tico designado por Donald Trump cuestion√≥ la injerencia en las provincias del pa√≠s asi√°tico, que replic√≥ con un duro comunicado. Fuerte rechazo de gobernadores y CFK.
resumen:
El gobierno de Javier Milei eligi√≥ el silencio ante las declaraciones de Peter Lamelas, designado embajador en Argentina por Donald Trump, quien apunt√≥ a la injerencia de China en las provincias y evit√≥ reconocer la soberan√≠a del pa√≠s sobre las Islas Malvinas.

La Embajada de China en Buenos Aires emiti√≥ un comunicado rechazando las palabras del funcionario americano.

Gobernadores de distintas provincias tambi√©n se pronunciaron en contra de Lamelas, a quienes se sum√≥ Cristina Fern√°ndez.

Lamelas se present√≥ ante el Senado de Estados Unidos para la aprobaci√≥n de su pliego.

Lamelas hizo una f√©rrea defensa de Milei, pero arremeti√≥ contra el federalismo en el pa√≠s y eludi√≥ pronunciarse a favor del pa√≠s sobre la situaci√≥n de las Islas Malvinas.

Lamelas dijo que buscar√° una alianza ‚Äúsin precedentes‚Äù con la Argentina y calific√≥ a Milei ‚Äúcomo actor clave en la regi√≥n‚Äù.

Lamelas traz√≥ l√≠neas preocupantes entre ellas la b√∫squeda de una ‚Äúbaja de aranceles‚Äù por parte de la Argentina para las exportaciones estadounidenses, lo cual impacta de lleno en la industria nacional.

Lamelas prometi√≥ ante los senadores estadounidenses que trabajar√° para evitar la inserci√≥n de China.

Lamelas dijo: ‚ÄúHay 23 provincias y cada una de estas tiene su gobierno por separado que pueden negociar con fuerzas externas, con los chinos u otros‚Ä¶ y eso, adem√°s, da lugar a la corrupci√≥n de parte de los chinos‚Äù.

La embajada de China en Buenos Aires public√≥ un comunicado en el que asegur√≥ ‚Äúlas declaraciones de figuras relevantes de Estados Unidos est√°n llenas de sesgo ideol√≥gico y de la mentalidad de suma cero propia de la Guerra Fr√≠a, lo que repercute negativamente en el resurgimiento de la ‚ÄòDoctrina Monroe‚Äô. Esto contradice los ‚Äòvalores democr√°ticos‚Äô que dicen defender‚Äù.

El gobierno de Xi Jinping se√±al√≥: ‚ÄúChina nunca ha buscado esferas de influencia ni intereses geopol√≠ticos, ni ha atacado a terceros. Argentina no debe convertirse en un escenario para los juegos de las grandes potencias, sino en un campo de demostraci√≥n para lograr la reforma, el desarrollo y la revitalizaci√≥n mediante la cooperaci√≥n internacional para el desarrollo. Recomendamos a las partes pertinentes no ‚Äòimitar‚Äô a China con su propia l√≥gica hegem√≥nica‚Äù.

Lamelas dijo que ‚ÄúEstados Unidos no reconoce la soberan√≠a sobre las islas ni para Argentina ni para Gran Breta√±a. Reconocemos la administraci√≥n del pueblo brit√°nico en la isla, pero mantenemos una posici√≥n de neutralidad sobre las islas‚Äù.

CFK se despach√≥ en contra del postulante a la embajada en Buenos Aires.

El Partido Justicialista rechaz√≥ los dichos de Lamelas por ‚Äúviolar el principio de no injerencia en asuntos internos de otros Estados, al entrometerse gravemente en la pol√≠tica de nuestro pa√≠s‚Äù.

Axel Kicillof subray√≥ que: ‚ÄúUn enviado diplom√°tico no puede comportarse como si fuera un tutor de las pol√≠ticas soberanas del pa√≠s que lo recibe‚Äù.

Sergio Zillotto se√±al√≥: ‚ÄúImposible callarnos ante tama√±a amenaza colonialista del designado embajador de EEUU en nuestro pa√≠s‚Äù.

Gustavo Melella sostuvo: ‚ÄúEn Tierra del Fuego, no nos dejamos disciplinar por nadie y decidimos con autonom√≠a‚Äù.

Ricardo Quintela manifest√≥ que ‚Äúlos embates contra la libertad y la soberan√≠a de nuestro pa√≠s avanzan con el aval y la aprobaci√≥n del gobierno nacional con total impunidad‚Äù.

title: Trump advierte aranceles de hasta 50% a pa√≠ses sin acuerdo comercial
content: Trump advierte que pa√≠ses sin acuerdo comercial con EE.UU. antes del 1 de agosto enfrentar√°n aranceles de entre el 15% y el 50%.
resumen: Donald Trump advierte que impondr√° aranceles de hasta el 50 % a los pa√≠ses que no logren acuerdos comerciales con Estados Unidos. El presidente de Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, reafirm√≥ este mi√©rcoles que a los pa√≠ses con los que no alcance un acuerdo individual antes del 1 de agosto les impondr√° aranceles que oscilar√°n del 15 al 50 %. Trump impuso un r√©gimen arancelario global del 10 % junto con grav√°menes considerados "rec√≠procos" para reducir el d√©ficit comercial con sus socios, a quienes dio como plazo inicial el 9 de julio para negociar pactos, margen que luego extendi√≥ de forma definitiva al 1 de agosto. EE.UU. solo ha cerrado acuerdos con el Reino Unido, Jap√≥n, Vietnam, Indonesia, Filipinas y China. Este √∫ltimo fue un convenio temporal que redujo los aranceles estadounidenses del 145 % al 30 % y los grav√°menes chinos del 125 % al 10 % mientras contin√∫an las negociaciones. A falta de acuerdos, el mandatario ha enviado ya cartas notificando aranceles de entre el 20 % y el 40 % a decenas de pa√≠ses, incluidos sus vecinos M√©xico (30 %) y Canad√° (35 %). A Brasil lo amenaz√≥ con un 50 % por el enjuiciamiento a su aliado, el expresidente Jair Bolsonaro. Trump dijo: "Cobraremos aranceles directos a la mayor parte del resto del mundo, porque tenemos m√°s de 200 pa√≠ses. Las conversaciones con la Uni√≥n Europea contin√∫an. Trump ha amenazado al bloque comunitario con grav√°menes del 30 %, pero fuentes diplom√°ticas confirmaron este mi√©rcoles a EFE que ambas partes se encuentran m√°s cerca de cerrar un acuerdo de aranceles del 15 % a los productos europeos.

content: Las tensiones arancelarias entre Estados Unidos y la Uni√≥n Europea se intensificaron en la administraci√≥n Trump. Las negociaciones se reactivaron en medio de presiones por evitar nuevos grav√°menes a ...
resumen:
Las tensiones arancelarias entre Estados Unidos y la Uni√≥n Europea se intensificaron en la administraci√≥n Trump. Las negociaciones se reactivaron en medio de presiones por evitar nuevos grav√°menes a las importaciones europeas a los Estados Unidos.

El canciller alem√°n Friedrich Merz expres√≥ este mi√©rcoles su optimismo sobre las negociaciones comerciales entre la UE y Estados Unidos que buscan un acuerdo antes de la fecha l√≠mite del 1 de agosto fijada por el presidente Donald Trump.

Merz declar√≥, al recibir al presidente franc√©s, Emmanuel Macron para una reuni√≥n de trabajo en Berl√≠n: ‚ÄúConocemos en este mismo momento que algunas decisiones podr√≠an ser tomadas‚Äù.

Seg√∫n el diario brit√°nico Financial Times, que cita a tres personas cercanas a las negociaciones, los europeos y los estadounidenses est√°n a punto de lograr un acuerdo comercial que impondr√≠a derechos de aduanas de 15% a las importaciones europeas, similar al acuerdo que acaba de lograr Trump con Jap√≥n.

Macron dijo estar ‚Äúen contacto permanente (...) con nuestros colegas europeos y con la presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea para seguir, impulsar, coordinar nuestra respuesta‚Äù a la ‚Äúofensiva‚Äù de los aranceles.

El mi√©rcoles se espera una reuni√≥n del jefe negociador de la Uni√≥n Europea, Maros Sefcovic, con su hom√≥logo estadounidense Howard Lutnick.

title: El surgimiento de la ‚Äúglobalizaci√≥n protegida‚Äù
content: Mientras el presidente de EU distancia a aliados y socios en todo el mundo, China se posiciona como una alternativa. Sin embargo, en lugar de sustituir una potencia coercitiva por otra, los pa√≠ses est ...
resumen:
Los aranceles del ‚ÄúD√≠a de la Liberaci√≥n‚Äù del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump fueron ‚Äúpausados‚Äù casi inmediatamente despu√©s de su introducci√≥n en abril, pero enviaron un mensaje claro: los pa√≠ses de todo el mundo deben adaptarse a una nueva era de diplomacia econ√≥mica coercitiva.

Para China, las acciones de Trump parecen una oportunidad para fortalecer su influencia global. El pa√≠s ha intensificado su estrategia de seducci√≥n, con la visita del presidente Xi Jinping a Camboya, Malasia y Vietnam para cerrar acuerdos bilaterales en materia de salud, tecnolog√≠a, agricultura y educaci√≥n.

China tambi√©n levant√≥ algunas sanciones contra la Uni√≥n Europea. En una reuni√≥n con su hom√≥logo nigeriano, el ministro de Asuntos Exteriores chino, Wang Yi, se comprometi√≥ a colaborar con los pa√≠ses africanos para ‚Äúrechazar el proteccionismo‚Äù, ‚Äúoponerse a la intimidaci√≥n‚Äù y defender la ‚Äúequidad y la justicia‚Äù. Wang declar√≥: ‚ÄúChina aportar√° certidumbre a este mundo incierto‚Äù.

China ha logrado un control efectivo sobre el flujo de tierras raras. En 2010, China detuvo las exportaciones de tierras raras a Jap√≥n durante dos meses debido a una disputa pesquera. En abril, suspendi√≥ dichas exportaciones casi por completo. China ha demostrado un patr√≥n de restricci√≥n de las importaciones de pa√≠ses con los que mantiene desacuerdos.

Los pa√≠ses est√°n adoptando una ‚Äúglobalizaci√≥n protegida‚Äù, mediante la cual cultivan redes de alianzas diversas que limitan su exposici√≥n a cualquiera de las dos superpotencias. El Sudeste Asi√°tico lidera el camino.

En la encuesta sobre el Estado del Sudeste Asi√°tico de 2025, la mayor√≠a de los encuestados expres√≥ su apoyo al fortalecimiento de los lazos intra-ASEAN.

Casi el 52% de los encuestados sobre el Estado del Sudeste Asi√°tico considera ahora a la UE como el segundo socio extrarregional de mayor confianza de la regi√≥n (despu√©s de Jap√≥n), frente al 41.5% del a√±o pasado, superando a Estados Unidos.

El viceprimer ministro de Singapur, Gan Kim Yong, adem√°s de redoblar los esfuerzos en la integraci√≥n regional, Asia debe establecer una alianza √°gil con socios afines. Singapur busca oportunidades con Chile, Per√∫ y el Mercosur, una mayor cooperaci√≥n con el Consejo de Cooperaci√≥n del Golfo y el fortalecimiento de la Asociaci√≥n Econ√≥mica Integral Regional (RCEP) y el Acuerdo Integral y Progresivo de Asociaci√≥n Transpac√≠fico (CPTPP).

El reci√©n nombrado ministro de Comercio de Corea del Sur tiene un historial de defensa de la participaci√≥n del pa√≠s en el CPTPP, que no incluye ni a Estados Unidos ni a China (aunque esta √∫ltima ha solicitado su adhesi√≥n).

Canad√° se est√° distanciando cada vez m√°s de Estados Unidos debido a los aranceles de Trump, sus llamados a convertirse en el estado n√∫mero 51 de EU y sus insultos personales. China impuso aranceles a varias importaciones canadienses; suspendi√≥ por completo las importaciones de carne de res canadiense; y detuvo a dos ciudadanos canadienses. El primer ministro Mark Carney ha impulsado acuerdos comerciales con la ASEAN, la UE y el Mercosur. En Am√©rica Latina, Brasil y M√©xico est√°n optando por forjar una cooperaci√≥n bilateral m√°s profunda.

La UE, cuya b√∫squeda de ‚Äúautonom√≠a estrat√©gica‚Äù refleja un claro deseo de reducir su dependencia tanto de EU como de China, a la vez que se protege de las amenazas que plantea Rusia. La presidenta de la Comisi√≥n Europea, Ursula von der Leyen, ha defendido el fortalecimiento de los v√≠nculos comerciales y de inversi√≥n con la ASEAN y el CPTPP. Suecia pide que la UE se convierta en miembro de pleno derecho del CPTPP, lo que crear√≠a una zona de libre comercio que representar√≠a casi el 30% del PIB mundial.

El surgimiento de la globalizaci√≥n protegida refleja el deseo de la mayor√≠a de los pa√≠ses de aislarse de la competencia actual entre las superpotencias.

Para que un sistema basado en la globalizaci√≥n protegida funcione, el liderazgo es vital. Las potencias intermedias deben colaborar para mantener un di√°logo basado en normas, crear espacio para que los estados m√°s peque√±os promuevan sus intereses y actuar como un ancla estabilizadora para la econom√≠a global.

resumen: La Uni√≥n General de Trabajadoras y Trabajadores (UGT) expresa su rechazo a la decisi√≥n de Donald Trump de imponer un arancel del 50% sobre las importaciones procedentes de Brasil. Trump ha anunciado la imposici√≥n de un arancel del 50% a todas las exportaciones brasile√±as hacia su pa√≠s, con entrada en vigor prevista para el 1 de agosto. Trump ha condicionado su pol√≠tica comercial a la suspensi√≥n del juicio contra Jair Bolsonaro, imputado por cinco graves delitos, una exigencia que vulnera la soberan√≠a institucional brasile√±a. El presidente Luiz In√°cio ‚ÄúLula‚Äù da Silva ha respondido con firmeza y ha anunciado que su gobierno activar√° su Ley de Reciprocidad Econ√≥mica. El real brasile√±o ha ca√≠do casi un 3% en dos d√≠as, y sectores clave como el caf√©, el zumo de naranja, el acero y la industria aeron√°utica ya anticipan p√©rdidas millonarias. Las principales centrales sindicales brasile√±as CUT, UGT Brasil y For√ßa Sindical, miembros de la Confederaci√≥n Sindical Internacional (CSI), han iniciado movilizaciones. UGT expresa su solidaridad con la clase trabajadora brasile√±a y con sus organizaciones sindicales. UGT reitera su denuncia de que esta ofensiva arancelaria no responde a ninguna l√≥gica comercial leg√≠tima, sino a una operaci√≥n pol√≠tica. title: S√°nchez pide que la UE cree un "fondo" de ayuda a "sectores afectados" con lo que se ingrese como respuesta a los aranceles de Trump
content: En su intervenci√≥n, el jefe del Ejecutivo espa√±ol aludi√≥ a que Trump haya anunciado que desde el 1 de agosto impondr√° aranceles a todos los productos de la UE. Entre los sectores m√°s afectados ...
resumen:
El presidente del Gobierno, Pedro S√°nchez, defendi√≥ este mi√©rcoles en Asunci√≥n (Paraguay) que si el mandatario estadounidense, Donald Trump, aplica finalmente a partir del 1 de agosto aranceles del 30% a todos los productos de la UE, lo que ingresen las autoridades comunitarias como respuesta a esta medida sea para crear un "fondo" de ayuda a "sectores afectados".

S√°nchez hizo esta propuesta al clausurar el Foro Empresarial Espa√±a-Paraguay junto al presidente de este pa√≠s, Santiago Pe√±a.

En su intervenci√≥n, el jefe del Ejecutivo espa√±ol aludi√≥ a que Trump haya anunciado que desde el 1 de agosto impondr√° aranceles a todos los productos de la UE. Entre los sectores m√°s afectados destacan el automovil√≠stico, el farmac√©utico, la industria del acero y aluminio, as√≠ como maquinaria, productos qu√≠micos y agricultura.

S√°nchez se√±al√≥ que la respuesta desde la UE debe ser conjunta, aunque los socios comunitarios quieren evitar "una guerra comercial en la que nadie gana" y "todos perdemos".

Si este enfrentamiento arancelario con Trump se materializa, "Europa debe estar a la altura de lo que esperan" sus empresarios.

Defendi√≥ que "los ingresos derivados de cualquier contramedida que se pudiera poner en marcha por parte de las autoridades europeas deben destinarse a la creaci√≥n de un nuevo fondo europeo de ayuda a los sectores m√°s afectados precisamente por estas tensiones comerciales".

El presidente se refiri√≥ a que su Gabinete ya adopt√≥ un "plan de respuesta y relanzamiento comercial" para paliar "los primeros efectos de la guerra comercial del aumento de aranceles que estamos viendo durante estos √∫ltimos meses".

Desde La Moncloa se ha dado una "respuesta r√°pida" a las tensiones comerciales, que han movilizado en Espa√±a 7.400 millones de euros y se han aprovechado como respaldo otros 6.700 millones "de instrumentos ya existentes".

S√°nchez a√±adi√≥ que tanto Espa√±a como Paraguay deben "defender" a sus empresas en este contexto de tensiones empresariales, al tiempo que destac√≥ la importancia de hacer frente al "proteccionismo" y el "ensimismamiento", en clara referencia a posiciones como la de Trump.

Impulsar la "apertura comercial" es lo que deben hacer tanto espa√±oles como paraguayos, algo para lo que dijo que ayudar√° el el acuerdo comercial UE-Mercosur.

Esta alianza es un "hito fundamental", no s√≥lo "desde el punto de vista econ√≥mico y comercial", ya que tambi√©n se est√° lanzando un "mensaje pol√≠tico" a los ciudadanos "de entendimiento, de partenariado, de comunidad, de objetivos compartidos".

El jefe del Ejecutivo concluy√≥ que Paraguay es para Espa√±a un "socio fiable" y con "gran potencialidad". Sostuvo que queda "much√≠simo espacio" para estrechar lazos entre ambos pa√≠ses y sus empresas para que se siga desarrollando la cooperaci√≥n entre ambas sociedades.

S√°nchez ensalz√≥ las infraestructuras realizadas y en proyecto de las compa√±√≠as espa√±olas, como el desdoblamiento de las rutas 2 y 7, y otros proyectos como el desdoblamiento y mejora de las rutas Asunci√≥n-Encarnaci√≥n y Encarnaci√≥n-Ciudad del Este, o la autopista elevada Asunci√≥n-Luque.
