title: Caf√© de Colombia, ¬øel m√°s afectado por los aranceles de Trump?
content: Un informe de la organizaci√≥n internacional de vigilancia Coffee Watch expuso c√≥mo los aranceles globales est√°n manipulados contra los pa√≠ses ...
resumen:
Un informe de Coffee Watch expuso c√≥mo los aranceles globales est√°n manipulados contra los pa√≠ses productores de caf√©, canalizando fondos hacia los m√°s ricos del mundo.

La escalada de la guerra arancelaria del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump agrava la crisis, con un nuevo arancel del 50% que se avecina sobre las importaciones estadounidenses de Brasil, el mayor productor mundial de caf√©, y aranceles adicionales sobre M√©xico, Vietnam y otros pa√≠ses, lo que podr√≠a agravar la situaci√≥n.

Seg√∫n Coffee Watch, fundada por Etelle Higonnet, las guerras arancelarias de Trump multiplicar√≠an la pobreza en los pa√≠ses cafetaleros.

Los aranceles ya han llevado a muchas comunidades agr√≠colas al borde del desastre, pero las guerras arancelarias de Trump amenazan con derrumbar econom√≠as rurales enteras, desde Chiapas (M√©xico) hasta Minas Gerais (Brasil) y m√°s all√°.

El caf√© tiene 25 millones de agricultores y 100 millones de trabajadores agr√≠colas; millones de vidas est√°n a punto de sufrir por los caprichos de un presidente estadounidense que usa los aranceles como su propio chanchullo.

Tras d√©cadas de importaciones libres de aranceles, la administraci√≥n Trump impuso un arancel del 10% a todas las importaciones de caf√©, con aranceles a√∫n m√°s elevados previstos para ciertos pa√≠ses productores.

Para pa√≠ses como M√©xico (que exporta el 39% de su caf√© a Estados Unidos) y Nicaragua (que env√≠a el 50%), las consecuencias ser√°n devastadoras y empujar√°n a agricultores ya de por s√≠ pobres a la pobreza extrema.

La mayor√≠a de los pa√≠ses productores, como Brasil, Vietnam, Colombia, Indonesia y Guatemala, podr√≠an verse gravemente afectados.

Miles de caficultores podr√≠an quebrar y muchas peque√±as cafeter√≠as podr√≠an desaparecer.

Las guerras arancelarias de Trump intensificar√°n un sistema ya peligrosamente abusivo: si bien los pa√≠ses productores representan el 74% del volumen de exportaci√≥n mundial, solo reciben el 57% del valor.

Las etapas de producci√≥n donde se a√±ade el mayor valor, como el tostado y el descafeinado, se realizan casi en su totalidad en pa√≠ses no productores, especialmente en Europa, donde los altos aranceles penalizan las importaciones de caf√© procesado.

Seg√∫n el informe de Coffee Watch, el 99% de las exportaciones de caf√© de los pa√≠ses productores son granos crudos, de bajo valor y sin procesar, a pesar de que el caf√© tostado alcanza m√°s del doble del precio.

Con muchos agricultores y trabajadores agr√≠colas ya por debajo del umbral de pobreza extrema, establecido por el Banco Mundial en US$2,15 al d√≠a, el aumento de los aranceles al caf√© hundir√° a millones en una crisis a√∫n mayor.

Los pa√≠ses productores de caf√© cultivan el caf√© y asumen los riesgos, pero se ven excluidos de las verdaderas ganancias por un sistema que beneficia al norte global.

Los aranceles al caf√© de la Uni√≥n Europea, el Reino Unido, Suiza y Jap√≥n han sido profundamente problem√°ticos durante a√±os.

Estos imponen aranceles tan altos al caf√© tostado o descafeinado que desalientan a los pa√≠ses productores a desarrollar industrias de procesamiento locales.

La mayor√≠a de los aranceles de los pa√≠ses consumidores penalizan a los pa√≠ses productores de caf√©, dej√°ndolos con ingresos limitados, aunque se espera que financien la respuesta a desastres clim√°ticos, subsidios a insumos agr√≠colas y la lucha contra la pobreza, todo mientras reciben solo una fracci√≥n del valor final de su caf√©.

Pa√≠ses como Australia, Canad√° y Noruega demuestran que un comercio de caf√© m√°s justo es totalmente posible, ya que no aplican aranceles al caf√© tostado ni procesado de otros pa√≠ses productores.

title: Expertos advierten los riesgos de la guerra comercial entre Brasil y Estados Unidos: "Puede afectar a varios pa√≠ses"
content: En una entrevista para La Rep√∫blica, Israel Dutra y Farid Kahhat, especialistas en asuntos internacionales, ofrecieron su perspectiva sobre la guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y Brasil.
resumen:
En una entrevista para La Rep√∫blica, Israel Dutra y Farid Kahhat, especialistas en asuntos internacionales, ofrecieron su perspectiva sobre la guerra comercial entre Estados Unidos y Brasil.

El desenlace de la guerra comercial entre Brasil y Estados Unidos contin√∫a siendo un misterio. Ante las amenazas arancelarias de Donald Trump, Lula da Silva respondi√≥ con determinaci√≥n y afirm√≥ que el pa√≠s que gobierna no ceder√° frente a las medidas impuestas a Jair Bolsonaro, motivo principal por el que Trump incluy√≥ a Brasil en la lista de 'pa√≠ses enemigos'.

La escalada comercial entre Estados Unidos y Brasil puede resultar perjudicial para ambos pa√≠ses.

Para Farid Kahhat, Donald Trump es una pieza clave en la guerra comercial entre Brasil y Estados Unidos. Tras m√°s de seis meses de gobierno, resalta que el presidente es muy vol√°til respecto de la imposici√≥n de aranceles. En contraposici√≥n, se√±ala que el caso de Brasil es tan arbitrario que podr√≠a ser llevado ante una corte de justicia.

Las grandes econom√≠as de Am√©rica Latina pueden verse afectadas por la devaluaci√≥n del d√≥lar, lo que representa una presi√≥n econ√≥mica por parte de Estados Unidos, en un contexto donde los principales pa√≠ses de la regi√≥n pueden enfrentar consecuencias en sus importaciones con ambos pa√≠ses implicados.

Por su parte, Israel Dutra, refuerza el peso de Brasil y Estados Unidos a nivel mundial, aunque advierte que toda escalada podr√≠a alcanzar niveles inciertos. "La idea de guerra, incluso siendo arancelaria, esconde conflictos, por lo tanto, agresiones. Esto directa o indirectamente puede afectar al comercio y a la econom√≠a de varios pa√≠ses. Esto provocar√≠a un da√±o futuro a√∫n incalculable", se√±al√≥ el dirigente del Partido Socialismo y Libertad (PSOL) de Brasil.

Kahhat asegura, no creer que Estados Unidos logre imponer una tasa del 50% de aranceles a Brasil. "Esto es el inicio de una negociaci√≥n", afirma. Sin embargo, se√±ala que Lula, antes de este "impase", no era tan conocido. Ante esto, los propios empresarios "bolsonaristas" no quieren que se apliquen aranceles a sus exportaciones, por lo que defender√°n la soberan√≠a de su pa√≠s, ya que consideran injusto aplicar estos impuestos.

La coyuntura actual favorece la posici√≥n pol√≠tica de Bolsonaro, asegura el especialista. Aunque descarta que Lula recurra al poder judicial brasile√±o para intentar evadir sus cargos, sostiene que encontrar√° una salida para evitar que todas las partes involucradas se vean afectadas.

Para Dutra, el gobierno de Brasil ha actuado correctamente en su gesti√≥n, invocando la ley de reciprocidad econ√≥mica. La opini√≥n de los principales actores econ√≥micos brasile√±os se basa en puntos positivos como la producci√≥n de acero, caf√© y productos de necesidad b√°sica.

El Supremo Tribunal Federal (STF) no tiene intenci√≥n de ceder ante el chantaje, por lo que visualiza con optimismo la idea de una amnist√≠a, adem√°s de una posici√≥n de fuerza brasile√±a que √©l mismo califica como "interesante".

Asegurando que no tiene la capacidad para liberar a Bolsonaro de sus cargos, Farid menciona que las sanciones perjudican principalmente a la econom√≠a de este pa√≠s, dentro de un conjunto de medidas que, seg√∫n sus propias palabras, son responsabilidad de las autoridades judiciales y del gobierno de Brasil.

El gran problema de Brasil radica en el d√©ficit comercial. Sin embargo, Kahhat asegura que existe la posibilidad de una concesi√≥n a trav√©s del BRICS, teniendo en cuenta las "actitudes complacientes" de Bolsonaro en tiempos de reg√≠menes autoritarios.

Dutra asegura que, si Lula acepta los pedidos de Trump, los peligros ser√≠an inimaginables, ya que afirma que la postura de Trump viola todas las normas de la soberan√≠a brasile√±a y los par√°metros del derecho internacional.

El polit√≥logo peruano no duda de que la alianza entre Brasil y China es una de las razones que motivaron a Trump a enviar la carta arancelaria a Lula. "Brasil tiene un alineamiento importante en el √°mbito pol√≠tico con China mediante los BRICS.".

Dutra es directo al afirmar que la postura de Trump es un ataque directo a los BRICS, una asociaci√≥n que incluye a China como aliado estrat√©gico, principal socio de Brasil en varias √°reas, algunas de las cuales generan mejor rentabilidad que las alianzas estadounidenses-brasile√±as.

El pol√≠tico brasile√±o se√±ala que, detr√°s del problema pol√≠tico que afecta a la soberan√≠a brasile√±a, existe un intento de impedir la expansi√≥n de lazos que Estados Unidos no puede controlar. Esto podr√≠a ser contraproducente para Brasil, ya que el efecto ser√≠a contrario al que Trump desear√≠a.

Kahhat asegura que Brasil deber√≠a liderar una respuesta conjunta en representaci√≥n de todos los pa√≠ses de la regi√≥n. Si bien hasta ahora no lo ha hecho, menciona que el contexto arancelario actual representa un incentivo, pero que, hasta el momento, solo observa un inter√©s de Lula a nivel individual.

Finalmente, se√±ala que "queda claro que no hay que confiar para nada en Estados Unidos", ya que, aunque se pueda negociar algo distinto, Trump siempre empieza con el pie en alto. Adem√°s, los pa√≠ses de la regi√≥n deben reducir su exposici√≥n a la econom√≠a norteamericana para no ser v√≠ctimas en el futuro de decisiones tan arbitrarias como esta.

Israel asegura que Brasil, con este enfrentamiento, tiene la oportunidad de destacarse como un pa√≠s de liderazgo multilateral, y no solo hacer frente a las medidas de Trump, sino tambi√©n a cualquiera que intente usar la fuerza para interferir en las reglas del comercio global.

"Trump est√° saliendo m√°s d√©bil, no m√°s fuerte", asegura Dutra, en fechas previas al 1 de agosto, fecha l√≠mite establecida para la entrada en vigor de los aranceles. Esta es una oportunidad para que Brasil lidere un bloque de pa√≠ses que se opongan a este tipo de subordinaci√≥n. Lula estuvo presente en los BRICS.

Uno de los pa√≠ses cuya soberan√≠a podr√≠a verse afectada, menciona Farid, es Panam√°. La intenci√≥n de Trump de tomar el canal de Panam√° y las amenazas de sanciones responden al intento de bloquear los puertos que conectan a este pa√≠s con las empresas chinas. En el caso de nuestro pa√≠s, record√≥ que el presidente estadounidense aplic√≥ un arancel del 10%, en una violaci√≥n al Tratado de Libre Comercio (TLC). "Nos est√° haciendo da√±o gratuitamente", sentencia.

Israel Dutra, por su parte, asegura que pa√≠ses como Groenlandia, Canad√°, y Panam√°, son algunos de los pa√≠ses cuya soberan√≠a podr√≠a verse afectada. Por el contrario, describe el caso de Argentina con Javier Milei, que se beneficia, ya que Trump se alinea con estas ideas respecto a la imposici√≥n de reglas, intereses y privilegios a otros pa√≠ses.

En una reflexi√≥n final, Dutra se√±ala que las amenazas arancelarias de Trump representan una oportunidad para que los pa√≠ses, no solo de Am√©rica Latina, sino tambi√©n de todo el mundo, fortalezcan sus relaciones diplom√°ticas en la regi√≥n, lo que √©l describe como "una posibilidad para que el mundo conozca la victoria".

title: No solo el Banco BRICS: en silencio, Colombia busca ingreso al Banco Asi√°tico de Inversi√≥n
content: En medio de la oposici√≥n y tensi√≥n de Estados Unidos a proyectos financiados y ejecutados por China en el mundo, Colombia habr√≠a solicitado ingreso al Banco Asi√°tico de Inversi√≥n en Infraestructura.
resumen: Colombia solicit√≥ su ingreso al Banco Asi√°tico de Inversi√≥n en Infraestructura (AIIB). El Gobierno envi√≥ en marzo una solicitud formal de adhesi√≥n al AIIB, banco multilateral internacional fundado en 2016 y con sede en Beijing. La incorporaci√≥n de Colombia como miembro del AIIB se formalizar√≠a en septiembre, una vez todos los pa√≠ses integrantes ‚Äîm√°s de 100 pa√≠ses de todo el mundo‚Äî otorguen su aprobaci√≥n. El presidente Gustavo Petro viaj√≥ a China en mayo y se reuni√≥ en Shangh√°i con Dilma Rousseff, presidenta del Nuevo Banco de Desarrollo de los BRICS. El ministro de Hacienda, Germ√°n √Åvila, y el presidente del AIIB, Jin Liqun, se reunieron para hacer seguimiento a la solicitud de ingreso de Colombia a ese banco multilateral. El Departamento de Estado de Estados Unidos advirti√≥ que se opondr√≠a a proyectos financiados por el BID y otras instituciones financieras internacionales destinados a empresas estatales chinas en Colombia. Colombia y el AIIB habr√≠an acordado manejar con ‚Äútono prudente‚Äù este proceso de admisi√≥n. El AIIB cuenta con 110 miembros, de los cuales 53 pertenecen a Asia y 57 a otras regiones, incluyendo Alemania, Francia, Canad√° y el Reino Unido. En Am√©rica Latina, siete pa√≠ses ya son miembros: Argentina, Brasil, Chile, Ecuador, El Salvador, Per√∫ y Uruguay. Bolivia y Venezuela figuran como miembros en proceso de adhesi√≥n.

title: S√°nchez arremete contra el ¬´proteccionismo¬ª de Trump en la primera visita a Paraguay desde Aznar
content: El presidente cierra su gira latinoamericana con un nuevo llamamiento a cerrar el acuerdo entre la UE y Mercosur ...

El presidente del Gobierno de Espa√±a, Pedro S√°nchez, culmin√≥ su gira por Latinoam√©rica en Asunci√≥n, Paraguay.

S√°nchez ha proclamado esa lucha contra el proteccionismo como un claro ¬´objetivo¬ª, y ha remarcado que ¬´solo podemos hacerlo asoci√°ndonos, trabajando codo con codo con socios estrat√©gicos y confiables¬ª.
S√°nchez ha detallado que la cooperaci√≥n espa√±ola lleva cuatro d√©cadas presente en Paraguay, con una aportaci√≥n superior a los 200 millones de euros.

title: Brasil condena en OMC aumento de aranceles de Trump
content: Brasilia, 23 jul (Prensa Latina) El embajador Philip Gough, secretario de Asuntos Econ√≥micos y Financieros del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de Brasil, conden√≥ hoy en la Organizaci√≥n Mundial del ...
resumen:
El embajador Philip Gough, secretario de Asuntos Econ√≥micos y Financieros del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores de Brasil, conden√≥ hoy en la Organizaci√≥n Mundial del Comercio (OMC), en Ginebra (Suiza), los aranceles arbitrarios anunciados por Estados Unidos.

Gough expres√≥ su profunda preocupaci√≥n por ¬´el uso de medidas comerciales como instrumento de injerencia en los asuntos internos de otros pa√≠ses¬ª.

El d√≠a 9, Trump anunci√≥ que su administraci√≥n impondr√° un impuesto del 50 por ciento a los productos brasile√±os vendidos en el mercado norteamericano a partir del 1 de agosto.

El representante brasile√±o enfatiz√≥ que tales medidas ¬´est√°n perturbando las cadenas globales de valor y corren el riesgo de hundir a la econom√≠a mundial en una espiral de precios altos y estancamiento¬ª.

Las sanciones unilaterales de este tipo ¬´constituyen una flagrante violaci√≥n de los principios fundamentales que sustentan la OMC y son esenciales para el funcionamiento del comercio internacional¬ª.

La presentaci√≥n de un recurso ante la OMC fue una de las medidas anunciadas por el presidente Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva, en un intento por detener la implementaci√≥n de tarifas a las exportaciones nacionales en Estados Unidos.

Desde que Lula comenz√≥ a mencionar la posibilidad de que Brasil apelara formalmente ante el organismo internacional, los diplom√°ticos evaluaron que el √≥rgano de soluci√≥n de diferencias de la instituci√≥n est√° paralizado e incapaz de actuar, e incluso si tomara una decisi√≥n, carece de la facultad para implementarla.

Una posibilidad ser√≠a que Brasil apelara conjuntamente con otros pa√≠ses afectados por el incremento de grav√°menes.

Para el Gobierno, las medidas de Trump constituyen un intento de interferir con la soberan√≠a del pa√≠s.

Lula comunic√≥ que considera responder con la Ley de Reciprocidad Econ√≥mica e imponer aranceles similares si las negociaciones resultan infructuosas.

La disposici√≥n permite al Ejecutivo adoptar medidas de represalia contra pa√≠ses o bloques econ√≥micos que impongan barreras comerciales, legales o pol√≠ticas contra Brasil.

title: Brasil denuncia ante la OMC las ¬´tasas arbitrarias¬ª de Trump y advierte del riesgo de una crisis global
content: Brasil ha presentado una queja formal ante la Organizaci√≥n Mundial del Comercio (OMC) por las amenazas arancelarias del 50% impuestas por Donald Trump a productos brasile√±os. La ofensiva del president ...
resumen: Brasil ha presentado una queja formal ante la Organizaci√≥n Mundial del Comercio (OMC) por las amenazas arancelarias del 50% impuestas por Donald Trump a productos brasile√±os. La ofensiva del presidente de EEUU ha sido calificada por el Ejecutivo de Lula como ‚Äúca√≥tica‚Äù y ‚Äúpeligrosa‚Äù, y podr√≠a derivar en una escalada global de precios y estancamiento econ√≥mico. La creciente tensi√≥n comercial entre Brasil y Estados Unidos ha escalado a nivel internacional con la denuncia formal del Gobierno de Lula da Silva ante la OMC. En el centro del conflicto est√°n las tasas arancelarias del 50% anunciadas por Donald Trump, medidas que han sido tildadas por Brasil de ‚Äúintervencionistas‚Äù y ‚Äúarbitrarias‚Äù. Esta nueva confrontaci√≥n amenaza con tener repercusiones m√°s all√° del comercio bilateral, impactando en la estabilidad econ√≥mica mundial. El Gobierno brasile√±o considera que las tasas no solo afectan al comercio, sino que buscan condicionar decisiones pol√≠ticas internas. Brasil acusa a Trump de usar los aranceles como herramienta de presi√≥n pol√≠tica. Durante su intervenci√≥n en la sede de la OMC en Ginebra, el secretario de Asuntos Econ√≥micos del Ministerio de Exteriores brasile√±o, Philip Gough, denunci√≥ que las medidas adoptadas por Washington ‚Äúpueden lanzar la econom√≠a mundial a una espiral de precios altos y estancamiento‚Äù. Gough critic√≥ duramente la nueva pol√≠tica econ√≥mica de Donald Trump, se√±alando que representa un caso ‚Äúextremadamente peligroso‚Äù de c√≥mo los aranceles se convierten en una herramienta de injerencia en los asuntos internos de otros pa√≠ses. La denuncia fue presentada a menos de diez d√≠as de que venza el plazo dado por Estados Unidos para imponer nuevas tasas del 50% a exportaciones brasile√±as. Lula advierte que Brasil usar√° ‚Äútodos los medios legales disponibles‚Äù para defender su econom√≠a si Washington no cede. Lula da Silva apuesta por el di√°logo, pero advierte con represalias. El discurso de Gough forma parte de la estrategia de Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva para frenar las amenazas arancelarias. Brasil mantendr√° su apuesta por el di√°logo, pero no descarta aplicar medidas rec√≠procas si la Administraci√≥n Trump contin√∫a con su pol√≠tica de presi√≥n comercial. Algunos analistas sugieren que la ofensiva arancelaria de Trump podr√≠a ser una forma de interceder a favor de Jair Bolsonaro, a cambio de impunidad en los procesos judiciales por su presunto intento de golpe de Estado. Las medidas de Trump podr√≠an dinamitar la estabilidad del sistema multilateral de comercio en plena recuperaci√≥n postpandemia. Brasil ha dejado la puerta abierta a que la Organizaci√≥n Mundial del Comercio medie en el conflicto si no hay avances por la v√≠a bilateral. La denuncia refuerza el papel del organismo en un momento en el que varios pa√≠ses del sur global reclaman mayor equidad en las reglas del comercio internacional. Esta confrontaci√≥n tambi√©n se produce en un contexto de creciente proteccionismo en varias potencias, encabezadas por Estados Unidos, lo que genera inquietud sobre el futuro de las relaciones comerciales multilaterales.

title: Geo-Economic Gamechanger: Washington‚Äôs New Strategy for Africa
content: Geoeconomics, defined as the use of economic instruments to achieve geopolitical goals, become a central element of states' foreign policy.
resumen:
Geoeconomics, defined as the use of economic instruments to achieve geopolitical goals, has become a central element of states‚Äô foreign policy. States use a wide range of geo-economic tools, from trade policy to sanctions, investment, cyberspace, development aid, financial and monetary policies, and energy and commodity policies. The aim is to promote and defend their national interests and achieve beneficial geopolitical results. The end of the Cold War resurrected the ‚Äúre-geoeconomization‚Äù of international relations. Edward Luttwak theorized a world in which state competition would be carried out by economic rather than military means. Robert D. Blackwill and Jennifer M. Harris insist that geoeconomics involves the use of economic instruments to produce favorable geopolitical outcomes. Historically, this approach is not new, as illustrated by mercantilism (1500-1750), where national wealth and military power were inseparable objectives. The ‚Äúeconomic weapon‚Äù emerged and became systematized, particularly during the First World War. During this period, countries such as Britain and France developed sophisticated techniques such as blockades to deprive the enemy of vital resources. Among these methods were the establishment of blacklists for companies trading with the enemy, preventive buybacks to acquire essential resources and remove them from the adversary, the financial blockade and asset freeze to control banking operations and ‚Äúnavicerts‚Äù, navigation permits to circumvent the maritime blockade. In the twentieth century, this approach continued to evolve; the Axis powers (Germany and Italy) sought autarky in response to blockades and sanctions, in order to reduce their dependence on vital imports. After World War II, the Marshall Plan was a notable example of the use of geoeconomic tools for geopolitical purposes, aimed at rebuilding Europe and containing Soviet influence. During the Cold War, embargoes and export controls were used against the Soviet bloc, such as the American embargo on ‚Äúred oil‚Äù in the fifties and sixties, or on cereals against the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan or Russia‚Äôs blockade of Ukrainian grain exports are eloquent examples.

Africa has become a central stage for the competition of the world‚Äôs superpowers seeking to expand their influence, marking a new ‚ÄúCold War‚Äù no longer bipolar but multipolar, involving mainly the United States, China and Russia, as well as former colonizers and other non-African middle powers (Turkey, Qatar, UAE, India). The aim of these powers is to convince African countries that their ‚Äúpartnership‚Äù is best suited to their needs, sometimes pushing the continent to choose sides, however, African voices, such as former President Macky Sall and Paul Kagame, insist on the continent‚Äôs right to sovereignty and non-exclusivity in its relations, claiming that Africa aspires to be a stage of international cooperation rather than an arena of competition between great powers wants to work and trade with everyone. The strategies of the superpowers in Africa vary widely: the United States promotes good governance and democracy on one side, African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) and USAID on the other, while criticizing China‚Äôs perceived coercive or ‚Äúdebt trap‚Äù practices. China, through the Belt and Road Initiative (BRI), dominates economic engagement with massive infrastructure loans and significant foreign direct investment, seeking to align the global economic order with its interests. While Russia focuses its engagement mainly on the military sector, being the largest supplier of arms to Africa, and is also involved in intelligence and security, but its economic influence remains weak compared to others. On overall, while China consolidates its influence through infrastructure and natural resource-backed loans, the U.S.A continues to wield power through its aid and market access through AGOA and soft power. The data analysis of the Formal Bilateral Influence Capacity (FBIC) Index from 2000 till 2020, developed by the Diplometrics Program at the Josef Korbel School‚Äôs Pardee Institute (which measures the formal influence that one country can exert over another across economic, political, and security domain) reflects a shift toward multipolar competition in Africa, with traditional Western powers losing ground to new assertive players, notably China and Russia, signaling a reconfiguration of geopolitical alignments on the continent. Between 2000 and 2020, China emerged as the most influential permanent member of the UN Security Council in Africa. Its influence grew rapidly from a low baseline to a peak around 2014, driven by large-scale infrastructure investments, strategic partnerships, and its Belt and Road Initiative. While France initially held the leading position, its influence gradually declined after 2017, reflecting growing resentment toward its presence, particularly in the Sahel. The United States maintained a steady influence for most of the period but experienced a slight downturn after 2016, possibly due to a strategic pivot toward Asia and diminishing engagement in African affairs. Meanwhile, Russia steadily increased its influence, though from a lower starting point, leveraging military cooperation, arms deals, and anti-Western rhetoric. The United Kingdom showed limited impact, with a slight rise until 2013 followed by a steady decline, likely accentuated by post-Brexit diplomatic and economic adjustments. Besides, the results of another in-depth analysis of the economic dependence indices of African countries vis-√†-vis the United States and China, which we carried out for the purposes of this article, reveal a geopolitical kaleidoscope of countries influenced by one or the other of the superpowers. Zambia, Angola, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Djibouti are among the countries most dependent on China, with high levels of debt, infrastructure investment and trade links with Beijing. These relationships are often strengthened by large-scale projects including railways, ports and energy facilities ‚Äì all pillars of China‚Äôs Belt and Road Initiative. In contrast, Lesotho, Eswatini, Burundi, and Sudan are classified as critical in terms of their dependence on the United States, mainly due to their heavy reliance on the trade benefits offered by the African Growth and Opportunity Act (AGOA) and U.S. aid programs such as USAID. For these countries, access to the U.S. market and development assistance are extremely important. Ethiopia stands out as the only African country heavily dependent on both China and the United States, while several other key players ‚Äì including Nigeria, Ghana, and Kenya ‚Äì having moderate relations with both China and the United States, giving them great strategic flexibility. Their ability to cooperate with both powers without falling into total dependence. Tunisia, Morocco, and Mauritius distinguish themselves as the most resilient African economies, demonstrating limited vulnerability to the competing influence of major powers. By pursuing diversified economic partnerships and balanced diplomatic strategies, they have effectively reduced their exposure to external pressures. In doing so, they seek to avoid entanglement in great-power rivalries; echoing the wisdom of the proverb: ‚ÄúWhen elephants fight, it is the grass that suffers.‚Äù

Category: Heavily dependent on China. Example country: Angola, Zambia, Djibouti, Ethiopia.
Category: Heavily dependent on the United States. Example country: Lesotho, Madagascar, Eswatini.
Category: Moderately dependent on both. Example country: Nigeria, Ghana, Kenya.
Category: Low dependency to Independent. Example country: Morocco, Botswana, Mauritius, Egypt, Tunisia, South Africa.

Empirical evidence confirms that China is more effective at converting its economic investments into diplomatic support than the United States, especially in mineral-rich and infrastructure-dependent economies. In contrast

title: Trump Announces Trade Deal With Philippines, Small Reduction in Tariff Rate
content: The U.S. leader said that Washington would apply a 19 percent tariff on Philippine imports, while Manila has agreed to remove all of its tariffs on American goods.
resumen: U.S. President Donald Trump announced a new 19 percent tariff rate for imports from the Philippines after a meeting with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. at the White House. Trump made the announcement on Truth Social, calling Marcos a ‚Äúvery good and tough negotiator.‚Äù Trump stated that the Philippines is going OPEN MARKET with the United States, and ZERO Tariffs. The Philippines will pay a 19% Tariff. In addition, they will work together Militarily. Marcos arrived in Washington for a three-day trip and met with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Secretary of State Marco Rubio, as well as U.S. business leaders. Trump announced that the two countries were ‚Äúvery close to finishing a trade deal ‚Äì a big trade deal, actually.‚Äù Trump claimed to have finalized similar deals with Vietnam, which negotiated a rate of 20 percent, and Indonesia, whose tariff is now set at 19 percent. The Philippines has agreed to remove nearly all of its tariffs and non-tariff barriers on U.S. imports, including quotas and import licensing requirements, and to bolster intellectual property protections. The U.S. had a goods trade deficit of $4.9 billion with the Philippines last year. A higher tariff rate will apply to any goods that are deemed to have been transshipped to the U.S. via the Philippines from any third country (i.e. China). The 19 percent rate will not apply if a certain percentage of a good ‚Äúoriginates from certain countries not party to this Agreement.‚Äù The rate for Vietnam has been set at 40 percent. The Philippines will cooperate with Washington ‚Äúto regulate the trade in national security sensitive technologies and goods through existing multilateral export control regimes, align with all unilateral export controls in force by the United States, and ensure that its companies do not backfill or undermine these controls.‚Äù The Philippines ‚Äúshall adopt and effectively enforce provisions to combat transshipment and other practices to evade or circumvent duties‚Äù and the U.S. ‚Äúshall work with the Philippines to streamline and enhance defense trade.‚Äù The U.S. has the right to terminate the agreement if the Philippines ‚Äúenters into a new bilateral free trade agreement or preferential economic agreement‚Äù with any ‚Äúcountry of concern.‚Äù The 19 percent tariff was marginally lower than the 20 percent threatened by Trump in a letter to Marcos earlier this month, but higher than the 17 percent announced in Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúliberation day‚Äù tariff announcement in April. It is also notably worse than the 15 percent rate that Trump announced today with Japan. Renato Reyes Jr. described the agreement as ‚Äúa grossly lopsided ‚Äòdeal‚Äô which is really more of an imposition rather than the outcome of any negotiations.‚Äù The national security analyst Justin Baquisal wrote that the lack of better treatment for US allies vs non-aligners is not doing anybody favors. Marcos is the first Southeast Asian leader to visit the White House since the beginning of Trump‚Äôs second term. Marcos described the U.S. as his country‚Äôs ‚Äústrongest, closest, most reliable ally,‚Äù while Trump praised the Philippine leader. Security and defense were also on the agenda. Security cooperation between the two nations has increased markedly in recent years as a result of China‚Äôs growing maritime power and ambition. The U.S. will come to the Philippines‚Äô defense under the Mutual Defense Treaty if its forces, ships and aircraft come under an armed attack, including in the South China Sea. Marcos told Hegseth that the assurance of mutual defense ‚Äúcontinues to be the cornerstone‚Äù of the U.S.-Philippines relationship. Marcos said that ‚Äúwe are essentially concerned with the defense of our territory and the exercise of our sovereign rights,‚Äù adding, ‚ÄúOur strongest, closest, most reliable ally has always been the United States.‚Äù Trump said that he would ‚Äúprobably‚Äù visit China ‚Äúin the not-too-distant future.‚Äù He said that the Philippines was independent in its dealings with Beijing. Trump told Marcos, ‚ÄúDo whatever you need to do. But your dealing with China wouldn‚Äôt bother me at all.‚Äù

title: An Alternative Tariff Strategy for the Trump Administration
content: As the tariff pause ends, the Trump administration should pivot to a more targeted and strategic policy that minimizes domestic harm.
resumen:
The article discusses an alternative tariff strategy for the Trump administration.

President Donald Trump's trade policy has become a focal point of public debate. The early months of his second term have been marked by tariff announcements, exemptions, and temporary suspensions. The imposition of reciprocal tariffs on April 2 triggered a global market downturn, retaliatory tariffs from other nations, and concerns over rising inflation and a potential recession. President Trump temporarily suspended his reciprocal tariff policy until July 9, extending the deadline to August 1 while announcing tariff rates countries would face without new trade agreements.

Over the last three months, the Trump administration has focused on securing trade agreements with all fifty-seven countries targeted by the reciprocal tariff policy. However, the administration has only negotiated trade agreements with Japan, China, Philippines, Indonesia, Vietnam, and the United Kingdom. All six agreements are limited in scope and offer modest concessions.

The Federal Reserve projects higher inflation and lower growth rates due to increased uncertainty surrounding trade policy and geopolitics. Walmart announced it would raise prices due to increased expenses stemming from the tariffs.

The core problem with President Trump‚Äôs tariff strategy has been its lack of focus and coherence. The administration outlined three primary goals: increasing federal revenue, reducing trade deficits and reindustrializing the U.S. economy, and eliminating unfair trade barriers abroad. Rather than tailoring specific tariff policies to address each objective, the Trump administration has opted for a broad, one-size-fits-all approach.

To generate revenue, the Trump administration should apply the principle of price elasticity. Inelastic goods (such as basic household necessities and products like coffee or prescription drugs) should be exempt from broad tariff measures. The administration can raise revenue by targeting sectors where U.S. importers have leverage and access to alternative suppliers. A more modest baseline tariff‚Äîsay between 3 and 5 percent‚Äîcould be more sustainable.

To reindustrialize, the Trump administration should adopt a targeted strategy that supports the reindustrialization of high-value manufacturing sectors and safeguards critical industries. The U.S. automotive sector is one example. The Trump administration should implement targeted tariffs designed to encourage foreign companies to relocate production to the United States. A phased approach could begin with modest tariffs, gradually increasing each year until reaching a predetermined cap in the high double digits.

When negotiating new trade deals, the Trump administration should recognize that most countries have sensitive sectors. If major trading partners prove unwilling to engage in meaningful negotiations, the Trump administration could consider imposing targeted import tariffs as a form of political leverage.

A more comprehensive, long-term dialogue is needed to define the nature of the U.S.-China relationship.

The extension of the ninety-day pause on the Liberation Day tariffs has given the Trump administration a brief window to recalibrate. The administration should first clarify its distinct trade objectives and then use tariff policy strategically to advance those goals.

title: EU and Japan strengthen trade alliance amid global tensions

Commission president Ursula von der Leyen and Japanese prime minister Shigeru Ishiba were present. The EU and Japan announced plans to strengthen their trade cooperation and combat economic coercion. The EU and Japan reaffirmed their support for a rules-based international trade order. The EU and Japan plan to step up the implementation of the trade agreement that has linked them since 2019. EU firms already export nearly ‚Ç¨70bn in goods and ‚Ç¨28bn in services to Japan every year and bilateral trade between both sides has increased by 20% since 2019. The EU and Japan also hope for more mutual investments. The joint statement also announces cooperation to reduce strategic dependencies, such as on critical materials, on which China implements export restrictions. The cooperation will expand to economic coercion and non-market policies and practices, with China in both sides' sights.

title: Albanese government weakens US and Western links
content: Warned by experts that the strategic environment is the most dangerous it has been since the second world war, it would seem that either the Albanese government has chosen to ignore ...
resumen: The Albanese government is weakening US and Western links, potentially moving Australia into Beijing‚Äôs orbit, despite Beijing's disregard for human rights. The evidence suggests the Chinese people would prefer to live in a land governed by traditional Chinese values. The Albanese government is making the same mistake of total reliance on the dominant power and avoiding making a full and proper contribution to the defence of Australia. Labor won only 34.5 per cent of the vote but was awarded 62.6 per cent of the seats. The voters were not informed that they were putting into office the most left-wing government that Australia has ever known. The government refused a very reasonable American request for help, to have an RAN vessel join the US-led operation against the Houthis‚Äô attacks on shipping. Calls from the US for Australia to increase its paltry defence spending have been arrogantly dismissed. Mr. Albanese has reluctantly and unsuccessfully tried to schedule a clearly inadequate meeting on the sidelines of an international conference with President Trump. Mr. Albanese has recently and pointedly seen Xi Jinping on the fourth occasion, and this on a six-day visit to communist China. Beijing is creating competition for our iron ore exports. Beijing spectacularly shredded both the Free Trade Agreement and the WTO rules when the perfectly legitimate suggestion was made for an international inquiry into the origin of Covid. The Albanese government has demonstrated that the Aukus nuclear submarines acquisition programme is proving extremely useful in creating the impression that the government remains committed to the Western camp. Beijing treats the Albanese government with a degree of contempt, as demonstrated by not even advising of live-fire exercises off Australia. Communist dictator Mao Zedong‚Äôs rule from 1949 to 1976 was disastrous, with Mao responsible for more deaths than any other ruler, between 60 and 80 million. The communists borrowed aspects of capitalism but retained their own iron rule and their access to unbelievable wealth and power. China became a criminal enterprise with a nominal attachment to communism. Jiang Zemin personally took the lead in the decision to eradicate the Falun Gong. The London-based China Tribunal, headed by prominent international lawyer Sir Geoffrey Nice KC, estimated there were 60,000 to 90,000 deaths annually from forced transplants. This appalling crime continues to this day and has been extended to the Muslim Uighurs. The Albanese government shows every inclination of bringing Australia closer to what is nothing more than a criminal enterprise and further away from the US and the Western alliance.

title: Flurry of trade deals offers relief for some Asian countries, while others wait
content: President Trump announced deals with Japan, Philippines and Indonesia, but many other countries have yet to clinch agreements.

title: Trump‚Äôs Tariffs Are the Highest in a Century. But After His Threats, They Seem Like a Relief.
content: The president imposed tariffs on Japan, one of America‚Äôs closest allies, that would have been alarming just months ago. And markets went up.
resumen:
Six months ago, few people would have anticipated that the United States would place a 15 percent tariff on exports from Japan. President Trump had campaigned on the idea of a 10 percent universal base-line tariff, plus a higher levy on China.

On Tuesday, Mr. Trump announced a trade deal that included a 15 percent tariff on Japanese products. Stock markets in Asia and Europe rose. The Japanese Nikkei 225 surged by over 3.5 percent, while shares of Japanese automakers, which will also be charged a 15 percent tariff on their exports to the United States, jumped more than 10 percent.

Mr. Trump has normalized tariffs at rates that would have been shocking just months ago. He has threatened higher tariffs on dozens of countries as of Aug. 1, unless they strike a deal with the United States. So far, the administration has announced deals with Britain, Vietnam, Indonesia and the Philippines, all of which have left tariffs of 10 to 20 percent in place.

The United States closed the deal with Japan on Tuesday. Negotiations between the countries had been difficult. The governments were also clashing over the 25 percent tariff that Mr. Trump had imposed on global autos, as well as Japan‚Äôs barriers to U.S. rice.

The key to clinching the deal appeared to be the president‚Äôs agreement to lower auto tariffs for Japanese cars to 15 percent. That is significantly lower than the tariff rates that cars from other countries will face, but still a huge increase from the 2.5 percent tariff in effect before Mr. Trump came into office.

Michal Jozwiak, a market analyst at Ebury, said the deal was ‚Äúa potential lifeline for Japan, as it represents a fairly significant concession from the Trump administration, while protecting the country‚Äôs vital automotive sector from harsher tariffs.‚Äù

South Korea, the European Union and Mexico, all of which are in active negotiations, seem likely to push for lower tariffs as part of their own deals.

The Japan deal reinforced ‚Äúthe perception that the White House is open to compromise,‚Äù Mr. Jozwiak said.

Economists have continued to insist that the higher tariffs will eventually start to weigh on the U.S. economy. Price increases have been slow to materialize but started to become more apparent in appliances, toys, furniture and other imported items last month. Economists anticipate that higher prices will weigh on company sales and consumer activity, resulting in slower growth for the U.S. economy.

Ryan Young, a senior economist at the Competitive Enterprise Institute, called the deal a ‚Äúlose-lose‚Äù for both Japan and the United States, saying it would lead to a sevenfold increase on the tariffs Americans are paying on Japanese products.

Matt Gertken, the chief geopolitical strategist at BCA Research, said there was ‚Äúlittle question that Japan would make concessions and come to a deal.‚Äù The United States consumes 20 percent of Japanese exports and 37 percent of its car exports. The United States also receives about 43 percent of Japan‚Äôs outward direct investment, and also ensures Japan‚Äôs national defense.

Analysts at Nomura said they were revising their forecasts, since recent tariffs had been more aggressive than expected. Mr. Trump‚Äôs tariffs on other countries seemed to be settling around 20 percent on average, rather than 10 percent, they said. And the 50 percent tariff the president has placed on foreign steel and intends to place on copper imports was also higher than expected.

The analysts said they now expect the average effective U.S. tariff rate to settle around 19.5 percent, potentially pushing up inflation and weighing on economic growth.

For Japan, a 15 percent car tariff is a hefty burden compared with domestic automakers that do not pay tariffs. But it will give Japanese automakers an immediate advantage over car companies in other countries that pay a 25 percent rate.

Patrick Anderson, the chief executive of Anderson Economic Group, said that the 15 percent tariff on Japanese cars would ‚Äúput heavy pressure on Germany, Korea and the E.U.‚Äù The 25 percent tariff could add costs of $15,000 or more to a luxury car from those countries.

title: Costa Rica registrar√° baja inflaci√≥n, tipo de cambio estable y crecimiento econ√≥mico moderado en segundo semestre de 2025

resumen: En su m√°s reciente revisi√≥n de perspectivas econ√≥micas, Grupo Financiero Mercado de Valores prev√© un crecimiento del 3,5% para Costa Rica este 2025, impulsado por la demanda interna y el consumo. Costa Rica concluir√≠a el segundo semestre de este 2025 con una econom√≠a en crecimiento moderado, una inflaci√≥n contenida por debajo del rango meta del Banco Central de Costa Rica (BCCR), y un tipo de cambio relativamente estable. El Producto Interno Bruto (PIB) del pa√≠s crecer√° un 3,5% este a√±o, impulsado principalmente por la demanda interna, y un 3,8% para 2026. El consumo interno se mantendr√° con un incremento similar al presentado en 2024. La inflaci√≥n se mantendr√≠a contenida y al cierre del a√±o llegar√≠a a terreno positivo, finalizando el per√≠odo en un 0,2%. Se proyecta un retorno al rango meta del Banco Central (3% con una variaci√≥n de un punto porcentual) hasta el cuarto trimestre 2026. El Banco Central continuar√° tomando decisiones prudentes respecto a la Tasa de Pol√≠tica Monetaria (TPM), que se mantendr√≠a en 3,75% durante este 2025. El d√≥lar se ubicar√° en un rango entre ‚Ç°505 y ‚Ç°515 hacia el cierre del 2025. El balance primario alcanzar√° un 1,1% del PIB al cierre del a√±o, similar al mostrado el a√±o anterior. Se proyecta una leve alza en la raz√≥n deuda/PIB, que se ubicar√≠a en torno al 59,9%. Hay seis principales riesgos que podr√≠an afectar el desempe√±o de las variables econ√≥micas a nivel interno: Menor crecimiento de exportaciones, Cumplimiento de la regla fiscal, Inseguridad, Traspaso de pol√≠tica monetaria a tasas del sistema financiero, Volatilidad en tipo de cambio, y Tensiones sociales e inicio de a√±o electoral. El PIB estadounidense tuvo una contracci√≥n interanual del -0,5% anualizado durante el primer trimestre del a√±o. La Reserva Federal (FED) ha mantenido su tasa de referencia sin cambios, pero el mercado a√∫n espera al menos dos recortes en lo que resta del a√±o.

El ministro de Econom√≠a, Carlos Cuerpo, defiende limitar las ‚Äútrabas‚Äù en el mercado interior para combatir el efecto de los aranceles a trav√©s de la simplificaci√≥n de "cargas burocr√°ticas para desplegar un ‚Äúmercado √∫nico completo‚Äù.
S√°nchez ha se√±alado que el objetivo en estos momentos sigue siendo ‚Äúevitar una guerra comercial‚Äù.

title: Estos son los pa√≠ses que deber√°n pagar la nueva tarifa de los Estados Unidos para obtener una visa
content: El Departamento de Seguridad en EE. UU. anunci√≥ que la nueva tarifa para la visa ser√° exigida a la mayor√≠a de los solicitantes de visas de no inmigrante y se aplicar√° a casi todos los pa√≠ses.
resumen:
El Departamento de Seguridad en EE. UU. anunci√≥ que la nueva tarifa para la visa ser√° exigida a la mayor√≠a de los solicitantes de visas de no inmigrante y se aplicar√° a casi todos los pa√≠ses.
El presidente de los Estados Unidos, Donald Trump, decidi√≥ implementar una ‚Äútasa de integridad‚Äù en las pol√≠ticas de seguridad fronteriza, por lo que todos los emisores se ver√°n obligados a aumentar el precio de las visas estadounidenses.
Esta nueva medida impondr√° el pago de US$250 (Q1 mil 920) adicionales hacia finales de 2025.
El nuevo precio para obtener una visa estadounidense de turismo o negocios ser√° de US$435 (Q3 mil 340), en comparaci√≥n con los US$185 (Q1 mil 420) actuales.
La nueva tarifa de US$250 ser√° exigida a la mayor√≠a de los solicitantes de visas para no inmigrante y se aplicar√° a casi todos los pa√≠ses que en la actualidad no forman parte del Programa de Exenci√≥n de Visas (VWP).
Actualmente, solo treinta naciones en todo el mundo forman parte del VWP: Andorra, Australia, Austria, B√©lgica, Chile, Croacia, Dinamarca, Estonia, Francia, Alemania, Grecia, Hungr√≠a, Irlanda, Israel, Italia, Jap√≥n, Nueva Zelanda, Noruega, Polonia, Portugal, Catar, San Marino, Corea del Sur, Espa√±a, Suecia, Suiza, Rep√∫blica Checa, Lituania, Luxemburgo y Malta.
Todas las naciones que no se encuentren en la lista del VWP deber√°n pagar la nueva tarifa de integridad a partir de finales del 2025.
Esto incluye a todo el continente americano, con excepci√≥n de Chile; por lo tanto, Guatemala y el resto de Centroam√©rica, as√≠ como M√©xico, Canad√°, el Caribe y Sudam√©rica, se ver√°n afectados.
La nueva tarifa afectar√° a quienes soliciten los visados de turismo (B-2), negocios (B-1), estudios (F-1), trabajo temporal (H-1B) y programas de intercambio (J-1).
Los US$250 adicionales representan el costo m√≠nimo legal establecido para el 2025.
Se espera que el DHS aumente el precio de la tasa de integridad mediante otros procesos de reglamentaci√≥n migratoria a partir de 2026.

title: How Trump turned the tide in his trade war
content: He is raising tariffs on some of America‚Äôs most important trading partners, and the world is largely cheering the agreements as victories.

title: Why automakers just scored their biggest win of 2025
content: Auto stocks rally globally after Trump announces 15% tariff deal with Japan, sending Toyota up 14% and spreading gains to US and European carmakers ...
resumen:
Wall Street automakers staged a dramatic turnaround Wednesday morning after President Donald Trump unveiled a game-changing trade agreement with Japan that sent car stocks soaring across three continents. The unexpected announcement triggered a buying frenzy that saw Japanese automaker Toyota surge 14 percent while rivals Honda and Mazda jumped double digits. The enthusiasm quickly spread to American and European markets, where investors rushed to scoop up auto stocks that had been battered by tariff fears.

Trump‚Äôs social media announcement outlined five major components that fundamentally alter the U.S.-Japan trade landscape:
*   A 15 percent reciprocal tariff
*   $550 billion investment commitment
*   90 percent profit sharing
*   Auto market access
*   Agricultural concessions

General Motors shares climbed 1.7 percent in premarket trading. Ford Motor edged higher by 0.2 percent, while Tesla rose marginally ahead of its quarterly earnings report.

German luxury automakers led the charge, with Volkswagen, Mercedes-Benz, BMW and Porsche all posting gains. Italy‚Äôs Stellantis, maker of Jeep and Chrysler brands, joined the rally alongside France‚Äôs Renault.

Japanese automakers experienced the most dramatic gains. Toyota‚Äôs 14 percent spike led a broader rally that saw Nissan jump 8 percent and Mazda rocket nearly 17 percent higher.

The ripple effects extended to Seoul, where Hyundai Motor surged 7.5 percent and Kia Corp added 8.5 percent.

Capital Economics analysts calculate the net effect reduces average tariffs on Japanese exporters by approximately one percentage point.

For American consumers, the deal could mean continued access to popular Japanese vehicles without dramatic price increases. The agricultural provisions also open new export opportunities for U.S. farmers.

The European Union and India continue negotiations as Trump‚Äôs August 1 deadline for elevated reciprocal tariffs approaches rapidly.

Jefferies analysts suggest the Japan deal‚Äôs success should substantially mitigate concerns about future trade uncertainty.

title: Trade Wars, ICE Raids Trigger Wave of US Small Farm Bankruptcies
content: After years of low crop prices and rising costs, America‚Äôs small farmers are facing a crisis brought on by higher interest rates, Trump‚Äôs trade war and dramatically reduced demand from China.
resumen:
Trade Wars, Rates Push US Small Farm Bankruptcies to 5-Year High.

July 23, 2025, 5:00 PM UTC.

Steven Church, Bloomberg News, Ilena Peng.

America‚Äôs small farmers are facing a crisis brought on by higher interest rates, Trump‚Äôs trade war and dramatically reduced demand from China.

In the first half of the year, small-business bankruptcies filed by farmers and fisherman hit the highest number since 2020.

Farm debt is expected to hit $561.8 billion in this year, a record high, according to the US Department of Agriculture.
